      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section.


          Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to
          karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259].
          Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a
          higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes
          [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how
          genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding
          ekspression regulation across different cell types
          [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3;
          @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved
          treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489].
          Previous studies has described different regulatory DNA elements
          [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248;
          @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene
          expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776].
          Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data
          [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002;
          @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved
          the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when
          dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific
          pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169;
          @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/baseline.txt
      vars: &ref_1
        test_description: Has no spelling errors
        title: >-
          Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns
          highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms
        keywords: >-
          genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic
          targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits
        content: >-
          Genes work together in context-specific networks to karry out
          different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations
          in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher
          level, affect disease-relevant biological processes
          [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how
          genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding
          ekspression regulation across different cell types
          [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3;
          @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved
          treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489].
          Previous studies has described different regulatory DNA elements
          [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248;
          @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene
          expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776].
          Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data
          [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002;
          @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved
          the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when
          dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific
          pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169;
          @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].
      response:
        output: >-
          Gene networks work in context-specific ways to carry out different
          functions, and variations in these genes can alter their functional
          roles and affect disease-relevant biological processes. To understand
          how genes influence complex traits, we must mechanistically understand
          expression regulation across different cell types. Previous studies
          have described various regulatory DNA elements, including genetic
          effects on gene expression across different tissues. Integrating
          functional genomics data and GWAS data has improved the identification
          of these transcriptional mechanisms, which are commonly dysregulated
          in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology.

        id: >-
          exec:python
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/src/llm.py
          --model ollama=mistral=7b-instruct-fp16
      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through
          gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug
          mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene
          co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of
          complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from
          the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and
          maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown
          formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure.
          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to
          karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259].
          Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a
          higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes
          [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how
          genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding
          ekspression regulation across different cell types
          [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3;
          @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved
          treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489].
          Previous studies has described different regulatory DNA elements
          [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248;
          @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene
          expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776].
          Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data
          [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002;
          @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved
          the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when
          dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific
          pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169;
          @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate_with_metadata.txt
      vars: *ref_1
      response:
        output: >-
          Context: Genes work together in context-specific networks to carry out
          different functions. Variations in these genes can change their
          functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant
          biological processes.


          Content: To understand how genes influence complex traits, it is
          necessary to mechanistically understand expression regulation across
          different cell types. Previous studies have described different
          regulatory DNA elements including genetic effects on gene expression
          across different tissues. Integrating functional genomics data and
          GWAS data has improved the identification of these transcriptional
          mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and
          cell lineage-specific pathology.


          Conclusion: This manuscript aims to address a knowledge gap by
          projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns and
          identifying disease etiology and drug mechanisms. By analyzing gene
          co-expression networks across different cell types, we hope to uncover
          new therapeutic targets and drug repurposing opportunities. Our study
          will contribute to the clustering of complex traits by integrating
          functional genomics data and GWAS data, providing a more comprehensive
          understanding of how genes influence disease-relevant biological
          processes.

          exec:python
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/src/llm.py
          --model ollama=mistral=7b-instruct-fp16
      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce
          jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to
          Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C)
          structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two
          sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the
          literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the
          knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision
          should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with
          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific
          articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These
          references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in
          formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the
          entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single,
          cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to
          karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259].
          Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a
          higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes
          [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how
          genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding
          ekspression regulation across different cell types
          [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3;
          @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved
          treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489].
          Previous studies has described different regulatory DNA elements
          [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248;
          @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene
          expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776].
          Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data
          [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002;
          @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved
          the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when
          dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific
          pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169;
          @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate.txt
      vars: *ref_1
      response:
        output: >-
          Context: Genes work together in context-specific networks to carry out
          different functions.


          Content: Variations in these genes can change their functional role
          and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes.
          Determining how genes influence complex traits requires
          mechanistically understanding expression regulation across different
          cell types, which should lead to improved treatments. Previous studies
          have described different regulatory DNA elements including genetic
          effects on gene expression across different tissues. Integrating
          functional genomics data and GWAS data has improved the identification
          of transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result
          in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology.


          Conclusion: This manuscript addresses the knowledge gap by providing a
          comprehensive analysis of how genes influence complex traits through
          expression regulation across different cell types. By integrating
          functional genomics data and GWAS data, we have improved our
          understanding of the transcriptional mechanisms that underlie tissue-
          and cell lineage-specific pathology, which can lead to improved
          treatments for these diseases.

          Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a
          higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes
          [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how
          genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding
          ekspression regulation across different cell types
          [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3;
          @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved
          treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489].
          Previous studies has described different regulatory DNA elements
          [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248;
          @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene
          expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776].
          Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data
          [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002;
          @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved
          the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when
          dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific
          pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169;
          @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

          Genes work together in context-specific networks to carry out
          different functions. Variations in these genes can change their
          functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant
          biological processes. In this context, determining how genes influence
          complex traits requires mechanistically understanding expression
          regulation across different cell types. This should lead to improved
          treatments. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA
          elements, including genetic effects on gene expression across
          different tissues. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data
          has improved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms
          that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell
          lineage-specific pathology.

          @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved

      vars: *ref_1
      response:
        output: >-
          Genes work together in context-specific networks to carry out
          different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations
          in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher
          level, affect disease-relevant biological processes
          [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how
          genes influence complex traits requires understanding expression
          regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9].
          Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements
          [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248;
          @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3], including genetic effects on gene
          expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776].
          Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data
          [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002;
          @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improved
          the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when
          dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific
          pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169;
          @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105]. However, there is still a knowledge gap
          in our understanding of how these mechanisms influence disease
          etiology and drug mechanisms [@doi:10.1038/s41591-020-0611-x;
          @pmid:27976062]. This manuscript aims to fill this gap by projecting
          genetic associations through gene expression patterns and highlighting
          the therapeutic targets and drug repurposing opportunities
          [@doi:10.1038/s41591-020-0611-x; @pmid:27976062].

          exec:python
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/src/llm.py
          --model ollama=mistral=7b-instruct-fp16
      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce
          jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to
          Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C)
          structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two
          sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the
          literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the
          knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision
          should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with
          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific
          articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These
          references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in
          formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the
          entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single,
          cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to
          karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259].
          Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a
          higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes
          [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how
          genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding
          ekspression regulation across different cell types
          [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3;
          @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved
          treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489].
          Previous studies has described different regulatory DNA elements
          [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248;
          @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene
          expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776].
          Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data
          [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002;
          @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved
          the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when
          dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific
          pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169;
          @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate.txt
      vars: *ref_1
      response:
        output: >-
          Context: Genes work together in context-specific networks to carry out
          different functions. 


          Content: Variations in these genes can change their functional role
          and affect disease-relevant biological processes. Determining how
          genes influence complex traits requires understanding expression
          regulation across different cell types, which should lead to improved
          treatments. Previous studies have described regulatory DNA elements
          including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues.
          Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data has improved the
          identification of transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated,
          commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology.


          Conclusion: Despite previous studies describing regulatory DNA
          elements, there is still a knowledge gap regarding how these
          mechanisms influence complex traits and contribute to disease
          development. This manuscript aims to address this gap by investigating
          the role of gene expression regulation in complex traits and its
          impact on disease outcomes. By integrating functional genomics data
          and GWAS data, we hope to identify novel transcriptional mechanisms
          that can be targeted for improved treatments.

          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through
          gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug
          mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene
          co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of
          complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from
          the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and
          maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown
          formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure.
          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to
          karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259].
          Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a
          higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes
          [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how

          [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248;
          @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene
          expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776].

          [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002;
          @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved
          the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when
          dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific
          pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169;
          @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].


          Revised paragraph:

          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate_with_metadata.txt
      vars: *ref_1
      response:
        output: >-
          Genes work together in context-specific networks to carry out
          different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations
          in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher
          level, affect disease-relevant biological processes
          [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how
          genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding
          expression regulation across different cell types
          [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3;
          @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9]. Previous studies have described
          different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247;
          @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3],
          including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues
          [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data
          and GWAS data has improved the identification of these transcriptional
          mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and
          cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169;
          @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105]. However, there is still a gap in our
          understanding of how these mechanisms lead to drug targets and
          therapeutic interventions [@doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z;
          @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9]. Our manuscript aims to fill this gap
          by projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns,
          highlighting disease etiology and drug mechanisms [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433].

          Context: Genes work together in context-specific networks to carry out
          different functions.


          Content: Variations in these genes can change their functional role
          and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes.
          Determining how genes influence complex traits requires
          mechanistically understanding expression regulation across different
          cell types. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA
          elements including genetic effects on gene expression across different
          tissues. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data has
          improved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that,
          when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell
          lineage-specific pathology.


          Conclusion: Our manuscript addresses the knowledge gap by providing a
          comprehensive analysis of gene expression regulation across different
          cell types and its impact on complex traits. By integrating functional
          genomics data and GWAS data, we have identified novel transcriptional
          mechanisms that contribute to tissue- and cell lineage-specific
          pathology. Our findings provide valuable insights into
          disease-relevant biological processes and pave the way for improved
          treatments.

          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to
          karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259].
          Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a
          higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes
          [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how
          genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding
          ekspression regulation across different cell types
          [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3;
          @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved
          treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489].
          Previous studies has described different regulatory DNA elements
          [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248;
          @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene
          expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776].
          Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data
          [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002;
          @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved
          the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when
          dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific
          pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169;
          @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate_with_metadata.txt
      vars: *ref_1
      response:
        output: >-
          **Context:** Genes work together in networks to carry out different
          functions, and variations in these genes can affect disease-relevant
          biological processes.


          **Content:** Understanding how genes influence complex traits requires
          mechanistically understanding expression regulation across different
          cell types. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA
          elements, including genetic effects on gene expression across
          different tissues. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data
          has improved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms
          that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell
          lineage-specific pathology.


          **Conclusion:** This manuscript aims to project genetic associations
          through gene expression patterns, highlighting disease etiology and
          drug mechanisms. By integrating functional genomics data and GWAS
          data, we will identify these transcriptional mechanisms that, when
          dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific
          pathology. This knowledge gap will lead to improved treatments for
          complex diseases.

          Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C)
          structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two
          sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the
          literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the
          knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision
          should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with
          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific
          articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These
          references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in
          formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the
          entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single,
          cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to
          karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259].
          Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a
          higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes
          [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how
          genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding
          ekspression regulation across different cell types
          [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3;
          @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved

          [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248;
          @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene
          expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776].

          [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002;
          @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved
          the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when
          dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific
          pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169;
          @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

          Context: Genes work together in context-specific networks to carry out
          different functions, and variations in these genes can change their
          functional role and affect disease-relevant biological processes.

          Content: Determining how genes influence complex traits requires
          understanding expression regulation across different cell types.
          Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements,
          including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues.
          Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data has improved the
          identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when
          dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific
          pathology.

          Conclusion: This manuscript addresses a knowledge gap by exploring the
          role of genes in complex traits, specifically focusing on expression
          regulation across different cell types. By integrating functional
          genomics data and GWAS data, we aim to identify transcriptional
          mechanisms that contribute to tissue- and cell lineage-specific
          pathology. Our findings have the potential to improve treatments for
          these diseases.

        id: >-
          exec:python
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/src/llm.py
          --model ollama=mistral=7b-instruct-fp16
      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section.


          Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across
          several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS
          relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms
          mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these
          approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual
          gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the
          network level.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/baseline.txt
      vars: &ref_24
        test_description: Keeps most references to other articles and doesn't make them up
        title: >-
          Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns
          highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms
        keywords: >-
          genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic
          targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits
        content: >-
          Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues
          [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
          @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an
          effective approach to identify these biological processes is the
          transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates
          expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a
          mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS relies on testing
          whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the
          association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these
          approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual
          gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the
          network level.
      response:
        output: >-
          The availability of extensive gene expression data across multiple
          tissues provides an excellent opportunity to identify biological
          processes [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
          @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. An
          effective method for achieving this is through transcription-wide
          association studies (TWAS), which integrate expression quantitative
          trait loci (eQTL) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for
          GWAS findings. TWAS aims to test whether perturbations in gene
          regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants
          and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. These approaches have been highly successful in
          understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level
          [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] and
          in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], as well as drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS operates at the individual gene
          level, which does not fully capture more complex interactions at the
          network level.

            assertion: &ref_27
              type: python
              value: >
                import re


                input = context["vars"]["content"]


                references = {
                  "@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838",
                  "@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6",
                  "@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776",
                  "@doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9",
                  "@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482",
                  "@doi:10.1038/ng.3506",
                  "@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889",
                  "@doi:10.1038/ng.3367",
                  "@pmid:33931583",
                  "@doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225",
                  "@pmid:31036433",
                  "@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w",
                  "@doi:10.1038/nn.4618",
                }


                # keep only references that are present in the input (this is
                needed because

                #  references might be removed from the input in some cases)

                references = [ref for ref in references if ref in input]


                # capture current references in the output using a regex

                output_references = re.findall(r'@[^ ;\]]+', output)


                n_fake_refs = len([ref for ref in output_references if ref not
                in references])

                return (n_fake_refs == 0)
        assertion: null

          exec:python
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/src/llm.py

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through
          gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug
          mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene
          co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of
          complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from
          the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and
          maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown
          formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure.
          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across
          several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS
          relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms
          mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these
          approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual
          gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the
          network level.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate_with_metadata.txt
      vars: *ref_24
      response:
        output: >-
          **Context:** Gene expression data is widely available in various
          tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
          @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9].


          **Content:** To identify biological processes from this data, a
          powerful tool is transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which
          combines expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a
          mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS tests whether
          perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association
          between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This
          approach has been highly successful in understanding disease etiology
          at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] and in disease-risk
          prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], drug
          repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS operates at the
          individual gene level, which does not capture more complex
          interactions at the network level.


          **Conclusion:** Our manuscript addresses this gap by projecting
          genetic associations through gene expression patterns to identify
          disease etiology and drug mechanisms. By analyzing gene co-expression
          networks, we can gain insights into the underlying biological
          processes that mediate these associations, which may inform
          therapeutic targets and drug repurposing strategies.

          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific

          cohesive paragraph.

          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;

          approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual
          gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the
          network level.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate_with_metadata.txt
      vars: *ref_24
      response:
        output: >-
          Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns
          highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms. This is particularly
          important when using transcription-wide association studies (TWAS),
          which integrate expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to
          provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. TWAS has
          been highly successful in understanding disease etiology at the

          @pmid:31036433] and in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w]. However, TWAS works at the
          individual gene level, which does not capture more complex
          interactions at the network level. This limitation highlights the need
          for further research into gene co-expression and functional genomics
          to identify therapeutic targets and drug repurposing opportunities
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618].

          exec:python
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/src/llm.py
          --model ollama=mistral=7b-instruct-fp16
      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce
          jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to
          Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C)
          structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two
          sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the
          literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the
          knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision
          should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with
          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific
          articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These
          references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in
          formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the
          entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single,
          cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across
          several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS
          relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms
          mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these
          approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual
          gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the
          network level.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate.txt
      vars: *ref_24
      response:
        output: >-
          Given the abundance of gene expression data across various tissues
          [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
          @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], a
          highly effective strategy to identify biological processes is the
          transcription-wide association study (TWAS). TWAS integrates
          expression quantitative trait loci (eQTL) data, providing a
          mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. The approach tests
          whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the
          association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. Successful
          applications of TWAS have not only shed light on disease etiology at
          the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also facilitated
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618].


          However, TWAS operates at the individual gene level, which fails to
          capture more intricate interactions at the network level. Therefore,
          there is a knowledge gap that needs to be addressed by exploring the
          use of TWAS in combination with other approaches that can account for
          network effects. This approach could potentially enhance our
          understanding of disease mechanisms and facilitate the discovery of
          new therapeutic targets.

          several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify

          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS
          relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms
          mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these
          approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual

        output: >-
          The extensive availability of gene expression data across multiple
          tissues provides a valuable opportunity to identify biological
          processes using transcription-wide association studies (TWAS). TWAS
          integrates quantitative trait loci (eQTL) data to provide a
          mechanistic interpretation for genome-wide association study (GWAS)
          findings. By testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory
          mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human
          diseases, TWAS has been highly successful in understanding disease
          etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] and in disease-risk
          prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w].
          Additionally, TWAS has been used for drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS works at the individual gene
          level and does not capture more complex interactions at the network
          level.

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through
          gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug
          mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene
          co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of
          complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from
          the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and
          maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown
          formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure.
          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across
          several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS
          relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms
          mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these
          approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual
          gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the
          network level.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate_with_metadata.txt
      vars: *ref_24
      response:
        output: >-
          Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues
          [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
          @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], a
          useful method for identifying biological processes is the
          transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates
          expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a
          mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS tests whether
          perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association
          between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these
          approaches have been highly successful in understanding disease
          etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] and disease-risk
          prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w].
          However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not
          capture more complex interactions at the network level. This gap in
          understanding can be addressed by combining TWAS with other methods
          such as functional genomics and gene co-expression analysis to
          identify disease-related pathways and therapeutic targets
          [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9].


          In summary, while TWAS is a valuable tool for identifying disease
          etiology at the transcriptome level, it does not capture more complex
          interactions at the network level. By combining TWAS with functional
          genomics and gene co-expression analysis, we can identify
          disease-related pathways and therapeutic targets that may be missed by
          individual gene-level analyses. This approach has the potential to
          enhance our understanding of disease mechanisms and drug repurposing,
          ultimately leading to more effective treatments for complex traits.

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce
          jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to
          Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C)
          structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two
          sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the
          literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the
          knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision
          should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with
          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific
          articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These
          references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in
          formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the
          entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single,
          cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across
          several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify

          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS
          relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms
          mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these
          approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual
          gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the
          network level.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate.txt
      vars: *ref_24
      response:
        output: >-
          Gene expression data is widely available across various tissues
          [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
          @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. To
          effectively identify these biological processes, a powerful tool is
          the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates
          expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a
          mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS tests whether
          perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association
          between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. These
          approaches have been highly successful in understanding disease
          etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] and in disease-risk
          prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], drug
          repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS operates at the
          individual gene level, which does not capture more complex
          interactions at the network level.


          In summary, TWAS is a powerful tool for identifying biological
          processes from gene expression data. While it has been successful in
          disease etiology, risk prediction, and drug repurposing, its
          limitations lie in its focus on individual genes, which does not
          capture complex interactions at the network level. Future research
          should explore ways to integrate TWAS with other approaches to better
          understand these interactions and their role in disease development

          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section.


          Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across
          several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS
          relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms
          mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these
          approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual
          gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the
          network level.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/baseline.txt
      vars: *ref_24
      response:
        output: >-
          Gene expression data is widely available across various tissues,
          making it an effective approach to identify biological processes.
          Transcription-wide association study (TWAS) integrates eQTLs data and
          provides a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings by testing
          whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the
          association between genetic variants and human diseases. TWAS has been
          highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the
          transcriptome level but also in disease-risk prediction, drug
          repurposing, and identifying complex interactions at the network
          level. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does
          not capture more complex interactions at the network level.

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through
          gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug
          mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene
          co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of
          complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from
          the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and
          maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown
          formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure.
          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across
          several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS
          relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms
          mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these
          approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual
          gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the
          network level.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate_with_metadata.txt
      vars: *ref_24
      response:
        output: >-
          **Context:** Gene expression data is now widely available across
          various tissues, providing an opportunity to identify biological
          processes that contribute to human diseases.


          **Content:** An effective approach for this task is transcription-wide
          association studies (TWAS), which integrates eQTLs data to provide a
          mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS tests whether
          perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association
          between genetic variants and human diseases, and has been successful
          in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level, as well
          as in disease-risk prediction and drug repurposing tasks.


          **Conclusion:** However, TWAS works at the individual gene level,
          which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level.
          Therefore, there is a need to develop methods that can integrate gene
          expression data with other omics data to identify disease-associated
          genetic variants and therapeutic targets. Our manuscript aims to
          address this knowledge gap by developing a novel method that combines
          gene co-expression analysis with clustering of complex traits to
          identify disease etiology and drug mechanisms.

          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the

          paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce
          jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to
          Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C)
          structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two
          sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the
          literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the
          knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision
          should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with
          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific
          articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These
          references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in
          formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the
          entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single,
          cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across
          several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS
          relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms
          mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;

          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual
          gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the
          network level.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-

      vars: *ref_24
      response:
        output: >-
          Context: Gene expression data is available across various tissues,
          providing a rich source of information for studying biological
          processes.


          Content: The transcription-wide association study (TWAS) is an
          effective approach to identify these processes by integrating
          expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data. TWAS tests whether
          perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association
          between genetic variants and human diseases, and has been highly
          successful in disease etiology at the transcriptome level as well as
          in disease-risk prediction, drug repurposing, and other related tasks.


          Conclusion: While TWAS works at the individual gene level, it does not
          capture more complex interactions at the network level. Therefore,
          there is a need to develop methods that can account for these
          interactions and provide a comprehensive understanding of biological
          processes. This manuscript aims to address this gap in knowledge by
          proposing a novel approach that integrates both gene-level and
          network-level data to identify complex interactions involved in
          disease etiology.

          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the

          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these
          approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual
          gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the
          network level.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/baseline.txt
      vars: *ref_24
      response:
        output: >-
          Gene expression data is widely available across different tissues,
          providing a valuable resource for identifying biological processes
          involved in human diseases. Transcription-wide association studies
          (TWAS) leverage this information by integrating expression
          quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic
          interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS tests whether perturbations in
          gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic
          variants and human diseases, and these approaches have been highly
          successful in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome
          level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433]. Additionally, TWAS has been used for disease-risk
          prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and
          drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS operates at the
          individual gene level, which does not capture more complex
          interactions at the network level.
