      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through
          gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug
          mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene
          co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of
          complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from
          the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and
          maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown
          formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure.
          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across
          several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS
          relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms
          mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these
          approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual
          gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the
          network level.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate_with_metadata.txt
      vars: *ref_24
      response:
        output: >-
          Gene expression data across multiple tissues is widely available, and
          an effective approach to identify biological processes is
          transcription-wide association studies (TWAS). This method integrates
          eQTLs data to provide a mechanistic interpretation of GWAS findings.
          TWAS tests whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate
          the association between genetic variants and human diseases. These
          approaches have been highly successful in understanding disease
          etiology at the transcriptome level, predicting disease risk
          (polygenic scores), and drug repurposing tasks. However, TWAS works at
          the individual gene level and does not capture more complex
          interactions at the network level. Our manuscript aims to fill this
          gap by using gene co-expression analysis to identify disease etiology
          and drug mechanisms through gene expression patterns.

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce
          jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to
          Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C)
          structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two
          sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the
          literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the
          knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision
          should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with
          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific
          articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These
          references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in
          formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the
          entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single,
          cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across
          several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS
          relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms
          mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these
          approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual
          gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the
          network level.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate.txt
      vars: *ref_24
      response:
        output: >-
          ## Context


          The availability of gene expression data across multiple tissues has
          provided a wealth of information for understanding biological
          processes and identifying disease risk factors.


          ## Content


          To effectively analyze this data, researchers have developed
          transcription-wide association studies (TWAS), which integrate
          expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a
          mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS tests whether
          perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association
          between genetic variants and human diseases. These approaches have
          been highly successful in understanding disease etiology at the
          transcriptome level, predicting disease risk, and identifying drug
          repurposing opportunities.


          ## Conclusion


          While TWAS has provided valuable insights into complex biological
          processes, it works at the individual gene level, which does not
          capture more complex interactions at the network level. Therefore,
          there is a need for further research to develop more advanced methods
          that can account for these interactions and provide a more
          comprehensive understanding of disease mechanisms.

          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify

        title: >-
          Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns
          highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms

          genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic

          TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory
          mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human
          diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these

          However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not
          capture more complex interactions at the network level.
      response:

          TWAS is a methodology that utilizes testing perturbations in gene
          regulatory mechanisms to investigate the correlation between genetic
          variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This approach has proven highly successful in

          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic explanation for GWAS findings. However,
          TWAS operates at the level of individual genes, which does not account
          for more complex interactions that occur at the network level.

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through
          gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug
          mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene
          co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of
          complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from
          the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and
          maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown
          formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure.
          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene
          regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants
          and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly
          successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the
          transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. Given the availability of gene
          expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings.
          However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not
          capture more complex interactions at the network level.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate_with_metadata.txt
      vars: *ref_42
      response:
        output: >-
          Context: Transcriptomic analyses of genetic variants and human
          diseases have been instrumental in understanding disease etiology at
          the transcriptome level.

          Content: Functional genomics approaches such as transcription-wide
          association studies (TWAS) have been highly successful in identifying
          disease risk factors, predicting drug response, and repurposing drugs
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. However,
          these approaches only focus on individual genes and do not capture
          more complex interactions at the network level.

          Conclusion: Our manuscript addresses this gap by using gene
          co-expression analysis to identify disease mechanisms that involve
          multiple genes. By integrating functional genomics data with gene
          expression data across several tissues, we can provide a mechanistic
          interpretation for GWAS findings and identify therapeutic targets that
          are more likely to be effective in treating complex diseases.

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce
          jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to
          Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C)
          structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two
          sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the
          literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the
          knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision
          should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with
          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific
          articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These
          references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in
          formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the
          entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single,
          cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene
          regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants
          and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly
          successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the
          transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. Given the availability of gene
          expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings.
          However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not
          capture more complex interactions at the network level.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate.txt
      vars: *ref_42
      response:
        output: >-
          TWAS utilizes testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory
          mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human
          diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This
          approach has been highly successful in understanding disease etiology
          at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] and in disease-risk
          prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and
          drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS only works at
          the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex
          interactions at the network level. Given the availability of gene
          expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings.
          However, TWAS only works at the individual gene level, which does not
          capture more complex interactions at the network level.

          and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;

          successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the

          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;

          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings.
          However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not
          capture more complex interactions at the network level.

      vars: *ref_42
      response:
        output: >-
          **Context:** Genetic studies have long been an important tool in
          understanding disease etiology and identifying potential therapeutic
          targets. However, these approaches often rely on testing for
          associations between genetic variants and human diseases, which can be
          challenging to interpret at the transcriptome level.


          **Content:** Functional genomics, such as gene co-expression analysis,
          has emerged as a powerful approach to identifying biological processes
          that underlie disease risk and drug response. TWAS (Transcription-wide
          Association Study) is one such method that integrates eQTLs
          (Expression Quantitative Trait Loci) data to provide a mechanistic
          interpretation for GWAS findings. While TWAS has been highly
          successful in identifying disease risk genes, it does not capture more
          complex interactions at the network level.


          **Conclusion:** Our manuscript proposes a novel approach that combines
          gene expression patterns with network analysis to identify disease
          etiology and drug mechanisms. By clustering complex traits based on
          their genetic and functional associations, we hope to provide new
          insights into disease pathways and potential therapeutic targets. Our
          study highlights an important gap in the literature by integrating
          gene expression data with network analysis to capture more complex
          interactions at the network level.

          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce
          jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to
          Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C)
          structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two
          sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the
          literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the
          knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision
          should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with
          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific
          articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These
          references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in
          formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the
          entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single,
          cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene
          regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants
          and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly
          successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the
          transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. Given the availability of gene
          expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings.
          However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not
          capture more complex interactions at the network level.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate.txt
      vars: *ref_42
      response:
        output: >-
          TWAS is a scientific approach that focuses on identifying
          perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms that mediate the
          association between genetic variants and human diseases. This method
          has been highly successful in understanding disease etiology at the
          transcriptome level, predicting disease risk, and repurposing drugs
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. However, the
          focus on individual genes does not capture more complex interactions
          at the network level. To address this gap, TWAS integrates expression
          quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic
          interpretation for GWAS findings. This method has shown promise in
          identifying biological processes across several tissues
          [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
          @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9].


          In summary, TWAS is a valuable tool for identifying perturbations in
          gene regulatory mechanisms that mediate the association between
          genetic variants and human diseases. While this method has been highly
          successful in understanding disease etiology, it does not capture more
          complex interactions at the network level. By integrating eQTLs data,
          TWAS provides a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings and has
          shown promise in identifying biological processes across several
          tissues. Further research is needed to fully understand the potential
          of TWAS and its limitations.

      score: 0.7142857142857143

          regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants
          and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly

          @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing

          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings.
          However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not
          capture more complex interactions at the network level.

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through
          gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug
          mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene
          co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of
          complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from
          the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and
          maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown
          formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure.
          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene
          regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants
          and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly
          successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the
          transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. Given the availability of gene
          expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings.
          However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not
          capture more complex interactions at the network level.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate_with_metadata.txt
      vars: *ref_42
      response:
        output: >-
          ## Context


          TWAS is a powerful method used in genetic studies to investigate the
          relationship between genetic variants and human diseases. It relies on
          testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate
          this association.


          ## Content


          The literature has shown that TWAS approaches have been highly
          successful in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome
          level, predicting disease risk (polygenic scores), and repurposing
          drugs [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. However, one limitation of TWAS is
          that it works at the individual gene level, which does not capture
          more complex interactions at the network level.


          ## Conclusion


          In this manuscript, we propose a novel approach to overcome this
          limitation by integrating gene co-expression data and clustering of
          complex traits. Our method provides a mechanistic interpretation for
          GWAS findings and highlights therapeutic targets for drug repurposing.
          By combining functional genomics with gene expression patterns, our
          study sheds light on the etiology of diseases and opens up new avenues
          for drug discovery.

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce
          jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to
          Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C)
          structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two
          sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the
          literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the
          knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision
          should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with
          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific
          articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These
          references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in
          formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the
          entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single,
          cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene
          regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants
          and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly
          successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the
          transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. Given the availability of gene
          expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings.
          However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not
          capture more complex interactions at the network level.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate.txt
      vars: *ref_42
      response:
        output: >-
          Context: The Transcriptome Wide Association Study (TWAS) is a powerful
          tool that relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory
          mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human
          diseases.


          Content: TWAS approaches have been highly successful in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], disease-risk
          prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and
          drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. The availability of gene
          expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9] provides an opportunity to identify
          biological processes using transcription-wide association studies
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings.


          Conclusion: While TWAS is an effective approach at the individual gene
          level, it does not capture more complex interactions at the network
          level. Therefore, there is a knowledge gap that needs to be addressed
          in order to gain a comprehensive understanding of disease etiology and
          risk prediction. Addressing this gap will require the development of
          new methods that can integrate network-level data into TWAS analyses.

          TWAS is a powerful tool that relies on testing whether perturbations
          in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic
          variants and human diseases. This approach has been highly successful
          in understanding disease etiology and predicting disease risk at the
          transcriptome level, as well as identifying potential drug targets for
          repurposing. However, TWAS only considers individual genes, which does
          not capture more complex interactions at the network level. To
          overcome this limitation, our manuscript proposes a novel approach
          that combines functional genomics with gene co-expression analysis to
          identify disease-associated biological processes and therapeutic
          targets. By clustering complex traits based on gene expression
          patterns, we can gain a mechanistic understanding of disease etiology
          and drug mechanisms at the network level. Our study will provide
          valuable insights into the molecular basis of disease and inform the
          development of personalized treatments.

          jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to
          Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C)
          structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two
          sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the
          literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the
          knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision
          should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with
          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific
          articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These
          references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in
          formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the
          entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single,
          cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene
          regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants
          and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly
          successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the
          transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. Given the availability of gene
          expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings.
          However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not
          capture more complex interactions at the network level.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate.txt
      vars: *ref_42
      response:
        output: >-
          ## Context

          TWAS is a scientific approach that aims to understand the association
          between genetic variants and human diseases by testing whether
          perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate this relationship.


          ## Content

          The literature suggests that TWAS has been highly successful in
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level, as well as in
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) and drug repurposing tasks.
          One of the advantages of TWAS is the availability of gene expression
          data across several tissues, which makes it an effective approach to
          identify biological processes. However, TWAS works at the individual
          gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the
          network level.


          ## Conclusion

          In summary, TWAS is a valuable tool for understanding disease etiology
          and predicting disease risk, but its limitations include the inability
          to capture more complex interactions at the network level. Further
          research is needed to develop methods that can integrate gene
          expression data across tissues and provide a comprehensive view of
          disease mechanisms.

          regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants
          and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly
          successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the
          transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. Given the availability of gene
          expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings.
          However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not
          capture more complex interactions at the network level.

          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene
          regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants
          and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly

          capture more complex interactions at the network level.

      vars: *ref_42
      response:
        output: >-
          **Context:** The study of genetic associations and their role in human
          diseases has been a topic of interest for many years.


          **Content:** Functional genomics techniques such as transcriptome-wide
          association studies (TWAS) have been highly successful in
          understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level and
          predicting disease risk through polygenic scores. Additionally, TWAS
          has also been used to identify potential therapeutic targets for drug
          repurposing. However, the approach of TWAS only works at the
          individual gene level, which does not capture more complex
          interactions at the network level.


          **Conclusion:** The current manuscript proposes a novel approach that
          combines TWAS with gene co-expression analysis to identify biological
          processes involved in disease etiology and drug mechanisms. This
          approach will provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings
          by capturing more complex interactions at the network level, which can
          lead to better understanding of disease mechanisms and the development
          of new therapeutic targets.

          knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision

          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific

          entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single,

        output: >-
          The Transcriptomics Workbench for Associating Sequences (TWAS) is a
          powerful tool in the field of genetics and disease research. It relies
          on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate
          the association between genetic variants and human diseases. This
          approach has been highly successful in understanding disease etiology
          at the transcriptome level, as well as in disease-risk prediction
          (polygenic scores) and drug repurposing tasks. The availability of
          gene expression data across several tissues provides an opportunity to
          identify biological processes using a transcription-wide association
          study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci
          (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS
          findings. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does
          not capture more complex interactions at the network level. 


          References:

          - [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]

          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the

          gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug

          co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of

          the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and
          maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown
          formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure.
          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across
          several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings.
          However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not
          capture more complex interactions at the network level. TWAS relies on
          testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate
          the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these
          approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks.

          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate_with_metadata.txt

      response:
        output: >-
          The availability of gene expression data across various tissues
          provides a valuable resource for identifying biological processes.
          Transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) can be used to integrate
          eQTLs data and provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings.
          However, TWAS operates at the individual gene level, which does not
          capture more complex interactions at the network level. Recent studies
          have shown that these approaches are highly successful in
          understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level, predicting
          disease risk (polygenic scores), and repurposing drugs
          [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433;
          @doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w; @doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, these
          studies have not explored the potential for identifying therapeutic
          targets and drug mechanisms using gene co-expression patterns. In this
          manuscript, we propose a novel approach that leverages gene expression
          patterns to identify disease-associated genes and predict their
          interactions with other genes in the network. Our findings will
          provide insights into disease etiology and drug mechanisms, which can
          be used to develop new therapeutic strategies.

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce
          jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to
          Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C)
          structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two
          sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the
          literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the
          knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision
          should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with
          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific
          articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These
          references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in
          formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the
          entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single,
          cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across
          several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings.
          However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not
          capture more complex interactions at the network level. TWAS relies on
          testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate
          the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these
          approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks.

        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate.txt
      vars: *ref_59
      response:
        output: >-
          Context: Gene expression data has become increasingly available across
          various tissues, providing a valuable resource for understanding
          biological processes at the transcriptome level.


          Content: However, traditional approaches such as transcription-wide
          association studies (TWAS) only provide a mechanistic interpretation
          of genetic variants and their association with diseases at the
          individual gene level. This approach does not capture more complex
          interactions at the network level. TWAS relies on testing whether
          perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association
          between genetic variants and human diseases, which has been highly
          successful in disease etiology, risk prediction, drug repurposing, and
          other tasks.


          Conclusion: While TWAS is a valuable tool for understanding biological
          processes at the transcriptome level, it does not capture more complex
          interactions at the network level. Therefore, there is a need to
          develop new approaches that can provide a comprehensive understanding
          of disease etiology and risk prediction at the network level.

          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across
          several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings.
          However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not
          capture more complex interactions at the network level. TWAS relies on
          testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate
          the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;

      vars: *ref_59
      response:
        output: >-
          Context: Gene expression data has become increasingly available across
          various tissues, providing a wealth of information for studying
          complex biological processes.


          Content: Transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) have emerged as
          an effective approach to identify gene expression patterns associated
          with genetic variants and human diseases. However, these studies focus
          on individual genes and do not capture the more complex interactions
          at the network level. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in
          gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic
          variants and diseases, which has been successful in disease etiology
          studies, risk prediction (polygenic scores), and drug repurposing
          tasks.


          Conclusion: While TWAS has provided valuable insights into disease
          etiology and drug mechanisms at the transcriptome level, a more
          comprehensive approach that captures network-level interactions is
          needed to fully understand the complexities of genetic associations
          with diseases. Our manuscript aims to address this gap by integrating
          gene co-expression analysis with functional genomics data to identify
          novel therapeutic targets and drug repurposing opportunities for
          various complex traits.

          **Context:** Gene expression data has been widely collected across
          various tissues, providing a wealth of information for studying
          biological processes at the transcriptome level.


          **Content:** Transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) have
          emerged as an effective approach to identify gene expression patterns
          associated with human diseases by integrating eQTLs data. TWAS works
          by testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate
          the association between genetic variants and diseases, providing a
          mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. However, TWAS only
          operates at the individual gene level, which fails to capture more
          complex interactions at the network level.


          **Conclusion:** While TWAS has been highly successful in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level and in disease-risk
          prediction, drug repurposing, and other tasks, it does not account for
          more complex interactions within gene regulatory networks. Our
          manuscript aims to address this knowledge gap by developing a novel
          approach that integrates both gene expression and network data to
          identify disease-associated biological processes at the network level.

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through
          gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug
          mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene
          co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of
          complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from
          the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and
          maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown
          formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure.
          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across
          several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings.
          However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not
          capture more complex interactions at the network level. TWAS relies on
          testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate
          the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these
          approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate_with_metadata.txt
      vars: *ref_59
      response:
        output: >-
          In recent years, advances in functional genomics have provided gene
          expression data across various tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. These datasets allow researchers to
          identify biological processes associated with genetic variants,
          providing insight into disease etiology and drug mechanisms. However,
          existing approaches, such as transcription-wide association studies
          (TWAS), focus on individual genes and do not capture more complex
          interactions at the network level [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. Our manuscript proposes a novel method that
          integrates gene expression data with functional genomics techniques to
          identify genetic associations through gene co-expression patterns,
          providing a more holistic understanding of disease etiology and drug
          mechanisms [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433]. By clustering complex traits, our approach can
          identify therapeutic targets and drug repurposing opportunities
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w]. Our study addresses a gap in the
          literature by providing a more comprehensive understanding of disease
          etiology and drug mechanisms through gene co-expression analysis,
          which has not been extensively explored before.

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce
          jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to
          Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C)
          structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two
          sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the
          literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the
          knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision
          should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with
          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific
          articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These
          references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in
          formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the
          entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single,
          cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across
          several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings.
          However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not
          capture more complex interactions at the network level. TWAS relies on
          testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate
          the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these
          approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate.txt
      vars: *ref_59
      response:
        output: >-
          Given the widespread availability of gene expression data across
          various tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS). This method integrates expression quantitative trait loci
          (eQTL) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings.
          However, TWAS operates at the individual gene level, which fails to
          capture more intricate interactions at the network level. TWAS relies
          on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate
          the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. These
          approaches have been highly successful in understanding disease
          etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] and disease-risk
          prediction [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, these methods do not capture the more
          complex interactions at the network level. Therefore, this study aims
          to address this knowledge gap by developing a novel approach that
          integrates gene expression data with network analysis techniques to
          identify biological processes associated with human diseases.

          offers an effective approach to identify biological processes.
          Transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) can be used to integrate
          expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data and provide a
          mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings at the individual gene
          level. However, TWAS does not capture more complex interactions at the
          network level. In order to understand disease etiology at the
          transcriptome level, approaches such as testing whether perturbations

          variants and human diseases have been highly successful

          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618], and have been used in various other
          applications.

          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify

          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)

          capture more complex interactions at the network level. TWAS relies on

          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;

        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate_with_metadata.txt
      vars: *ref_59
      response:
        output: >-
          Context: Gene expression data are increasingly available across
          various tissues, providing valuable insights into the molecular
          mechanisms underlying human diseases. However, these datasets often
          contain complex interactions between genes that cannot be fully
          captured by analyzing individual gene expression patterns.


          Content: Functional genomics approaches, such as transcription-wide
          association studies (TWAS), have been successful in identifying
          genetic associations with disease etiology and drug mechanisms at the
          transcriptome level. TWAS integrates eQTLs data to provide a
          mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings, allowing researchers to
          test whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the
          association between genetic variants and human diseases.


          Conclusion: While TWAS has been successful in understanding disease
          etiology at the transcriptome level and predicting disease risk
          through polygenic scores, it does not capture more complex
          interactions at the network level. Our manuscript aims to address this
          gap by projecting genetic associations through gene expression
          patterns, highlighting disease etiology and drug mechanisms at a
          systems level. By leveraging clustering of complex traits, we aim to
          uncover novel therapeutic targets for diseases that are not well
          understood or have limited treatment options.

          Context: Gene expression data is available across multiple tissues,
          providing a wealth of information for studying biological processes.


          Content: One effective method to analyze this data is through
          transcription-wide association studies (TWAS), which integrate
          expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a
          mechanistic interpretation for genome-wide association study (GWAS)
          findings. However, TWAS only considers individual genes and does not
          capture more complex interactions at the network level.


          Conclusion: While TWAS has been highly successful in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level, it relies on testing
          whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the
          association between genetic variants and human diseases. This approach
          only considers individual genes and does not capture more complex
          interactions at the network level, which is a limitation that needs to
          be addressed.

          Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across
          several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings.
          However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not
          capture more complex interactions at the network level. TWAS relies on
          testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate
          the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these
          approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/baseline.txt
      vars: *ref_59
      response:
        output: >-
          The availability of gene expression data across multiple tissues has
          provided an opportunity to identify biological processes using
          transcription-wide association studies (TWAS). TWAS integrates
          expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a
          mechanistic interpretation for genetic variants associated with human
          diseases. However, TWAS operates at the individual gene level and does
          not capture more complex interactions at the network level.


          TWAS tests whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate
          the association between genetic variants and human diseases. These
          approaches have been highly successful in understanding disease
          etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] and in disease-risk
          prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], drug
          repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618], and in identifying novel
          therapeutic targets [@doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9].

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through
          gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug
          mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene
          co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of
          complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from
          the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and
          maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown
          formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure.
          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across
          several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings.
          However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not
          capture more complex interactions at the network level. TWAS relies on
          testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate
          the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these
          approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate_with_metadata.txt
      vars: *ref_59
      response:
        output: >-
          Context: The availability of gene expression data across various
          tissues provides a valuable resource for identifying biological
          processes related to human diseases. However, traditional approaches
          like transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) only focus on
          individual genes and do not capture the complexity of interactions at
          the network level.


          Content: TWAS uses eQTLs data to provide a mechanistic interpretation
          for GWAS findings, but it works at the individual gene level. This
          approach has been highly successful in understanding disease etiology
          at the transcriptome level and in disease-risk prediction (polygenic
          scores) and drug repurposing tasks.


          Conclusion: Our manuscript aims to address this gap by projecting
          genetic associations through gene expression patterns, which
          highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms at a network level. By
          combining eQTLs data with clustering of complex traits, we can
          identify disease-associated genes and pathways that may not have been
          captured by traditional approaches. This will provide new insights
          into the underlying mechanisms of human diseases and lead to the
          discovery of novel therapeutic targets.
