      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce
          jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to
          Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C)
          structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two
          sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the
          literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the
          knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision
          should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with
          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific
          articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These
          references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in
          formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the
          entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single,
          cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across
          several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings.
          However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not
          capture more complex interactions at the network level. TWAS relies on
          testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate
          the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these
          approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate.txt
      vars: *ref_59
      response:
        output: >-
          Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues,
          an effective approach to identify biological processes is
          transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates
          expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a
          mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. However, TWAS works at
          the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex
          interactions at the network level. TWAS relies on testing whether
          perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association
          between genetic variants and human diseases. These approaches have
          been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at
          the transcriptome level but also in disease-risk prediction, drug
          repurposing, and polygenic scores tasks. Despite its success, TWAS
          does not fully capture the complexity of interactions within gene
          regulatory networks. Thus, there is a knowledge gap that needs to be
          addressed by developing more advanced methods that can capture these
          complex interactions.

        id: >-
          exec:python
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/src/llm.py
          --model ollama=mistral=7b-instruct-fp16
      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section.


          Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
          that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
          flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities
          into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this
          module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands
          of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring
          the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different
          complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act
          together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This
          approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/baseline.txt
      vars: &ref_76
        test_description: has proper last paragraph structure
        title: >-
          Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns
          highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms
        keywords: >-
          genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic
          targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits
        content: >-
          Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach that provides a gene
          module perspective to genetic studies. The flexibility of our method
          allows integrating different data modalities into the same
          representation for a joint analysis. We show that this module
          perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands
          of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring
          the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different
          complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act
          together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This
          approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.
      response:
        output: >-
          In this manuscript, we present PhenoPLIER, an innovative approach that
          integrates gene modules into genetic studies. By combining different
          data modalities into a single representation, our method enables joint
          analysis of complex traits and allows for the discovery of shared and
          distinct transcriptomic properties among them. We demonstrate how
          PhenoPLIER can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect drug-induced transcriptional
          responses, and predict their effects on gene activity to exert
          therapeutic outcomes. 


          To achieve this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait associations
          (from TWAS in PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and
          transcriptional profiles of drugs (from LINCS L1000
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a low-dimensional space
          learned from public gene expression data on tens of thousands of
          RNA-seq samples (recount2 [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003;
          @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a latent representation defined by
          matrix factorization approaches that extract gene modules with
          specific sparsity constraints and preferences for those that align
          with prior knowledge (pathways). Our results show that diseases are
          significantly associated with gene modules expressed in relevant cell
          types, such as hypothyroidism with T cells or corneal endothelial
          cells with keratometry measurements. Furthermore, we observe that
          significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan (our discovery
          cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records and Genomics
          (eMERGE) network phase III (our replication cohort). 


          Our approach also demonstrates improved drug-disease prediction by
          capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with
          the mechanism of action of drugs. For instance, we observe that niacin
          is associated with cardiovascular traits via an immune mechanism in
          liver cells. Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based
          method also better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by
          capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with
          the mechanism of action of drugs. 


          Finally, exploring the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait
          clusters associated with relevant tissues, including a complex branch
          involving lipids with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric
          disorders. In summary, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that
          act together to carry out different functions in specific cell types,
          which improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations and prioritizes alternative and potentially more
          promising candidate targets even when known single gene associations
          are not detected. Our approach represents a conceptual shift in the
          interpretation of genetic studies and has the potential to extract
          mechanistic insight from statistical associations to enhance the
          understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.
      success: false

          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through
          gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug

          co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of

          the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and
          maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown
          formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure.
          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
          that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
          flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities
          into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this
          module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands
          of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring
          the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different
          complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act
          together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This
          approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.

        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate_with_metadata.txt

        output: >-
          We propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach that provides a gene
          module perspective for genetic studies. Our method allows integrating
          different data modalities into the same representation for joint
          analysis. We show that this module perspective can infer how groups of
          functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect shared and
          distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict how
          pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert their
          effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and drug-induced
          transcriptional responses into a common latent representation by
          integrating thousands of gene-trait associations (from TWAS from
          PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional
          profiles of drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049])
          into a low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data
          on tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). We
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large and
          heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets to identify modules associated with
          cell types under specific stimuli or disease states. We observe that
          significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan (our discovery
          cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records and Genomics
          (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells and observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring
          the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          summary, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act together to
          carry out different functions in specific cell types, improving
          robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic associations and
          prioritizing alternative and potentially more promising candidate
          targets even when known single gene associations are not detected.
          This approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation of
          genetic studies, with the potential to extract mechanistic insight
          from statistical associations to enhance the understanding of complex
          diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce
          jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to
          Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C)
          structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two
          sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the
          literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the
          knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision
          should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with
          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific
          articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These
          references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in
          formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the
          entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single,
          cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
          that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
          flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities
          into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this
          module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands
          of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring
          the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different
          complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act
          together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This
          approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.

      response:
        output: >-
          Context: Genetic studies have traditionally focused on single genes,
          but recent advances in technology and methodology have enabled a more
          holistic approach to understanding gene function and disease
          mechanisms. 

          Content: PhenoPLIER is an omnigenic method that integrates different
          data modalities into a common latent representation for joint
          analysis. This module perspective allows for the inference of how
          groups of functionally-related genes influence complex traits,
          detection of shared and distinct transcriptomic properties among
          traits, and prediction of how pharmacological perturbations affect
          genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait
          associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples. The method uses a latent
          representation defined by a matrix factorization approach that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). 

          Conclusion: PhenoPLIER's module perspective provides a more robust and
          interpretable approach to genetic studies. By analyzing groups of
          genes that act together in specific cell types, PhenoPLIER improves
          the detection and interpretation of genetic associations. The method
          can prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate
          targets even when known single gene associations are not detected.
          Furthermore, PhenoPLIER's drug-disease prediction suggests that
          modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease
          relationships than individual genes. Overall, PhenoPLIER represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies and has the
          potential to enhance our understanding of complex diseases and their
          therapeutic modalities.

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section.


          Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
          that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
          flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities
          into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this
          module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands
          of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring
          the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different
          complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act
          together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This
          approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/baseline.txt
      vars: *ref_76
      response:
        output: >-
          In this manuscript, we propose PhenoPLIER, an innovative method that
          integrates gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional
          responses into a common latent representation to provide a gene module
          perspective for genetic studies. Our approach is omnigenic and can
          integrate different data modalities into the same representation for
          joint analysis. We demonstrate that PhenoPLIER can infer how groups of
          functionally related genes influence complex traits, detect shared and
          distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict how
          pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert their
          effects.


          To achieve this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait associations
          (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and
          transcriptional profiles of drugs (from LINCS L1000
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a low-dimensional space
          learned from public gene expression data on tens of thousands of
          RNA-seq samples (recount2 [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003;
          @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] to
          extract gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and preferences
          for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). We observe that
          diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in
          relevant cell types, such as hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal
          endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological assays
          on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and
          neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types.


          Our approach can also use models derived from large and heterogeneous
          RNA-seq datasets to identify modules associated with cell types under
          specific stimuli or disease states. We observe that significant
          module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort)
          replicated in the Electronic Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE)
          network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells and observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          This improved drug-disease prediction suggests that modules may
          provide a better means to examine drug-disease relationships than
          individual genes.


          Finally, exploring the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait
          clusters associated with relevant tissues, including a complex branch
          involving lipids with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric
          disorders. In summary, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that
          act together to carry out different functions in specific cell types,
          improving robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations and providing a better means to prioritize alternative
          and potentially more promising candidate targets even when known
          single gene associations are not detected. Our approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies and has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance our understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.

          --model ollama=mistral=7b-instruct-fp16
      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through
          gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug
          mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene
          co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of
          complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from
          the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and
          maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown
          formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure.
          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
          that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
          flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities
          into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this
          module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands
          of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring
          the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different
          complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act
          together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This
          approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate_with_metadata.txt
      vars: *ref_76
      response:
        output: >-
          We propose an omnigenic approach called PhenoPLIER that integrates
          gene expression data with other types of molecular and clinical data
          to study genetic associations and drug mechanisms. Our method allows
          for a joint analysis of multiple data modalities, including genomic,
          transcriptomic, epigenomic, and clinical data, into a common latent
          space. We show that this module perspective can identify functional
          relationships between genes and complex traits, detect shared and
          distinct molecular properties among traits, and predict how
          pharmacological perturbations affect gene activity to exert their
          effects.


          To achieve these goals, we integrate thousands of gene-trait
          associations from TWAS in PhenomeXcan with transcriptional profiles of
          drugs from LINCS L1000 into a low-dimensional space learned from
          public gene expression data on tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples.
          We use a latent representation defined by matrix factorization that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe significant correlations between diseases and gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types.


          We also show that PhenoPLIER can identify modules associated with cell
          types under specific stimuli or disease states. Our approach has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance our understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities. For example, we observe that significant module-trait
          associations in our discovery cohort replicated in the Electronic
          Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III, suggesting
          that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease
          relationships than individual genes. Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR
          screen to analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells and observe more
          robust trait associations with modules than with individual genes,
          even when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did
          not reach genome-wide significance.


          In conclusion, our omnigenic approach can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected, providing a conceptual shift in
          the interpretation of genetic studies. PhenoPLIER has the potential to
          improve robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic associations,
          and its ability to integrate multiple data modalities makes it a
          valuable tool for drug discovery and precision medicine.

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce
          jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to
          Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C)
          structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two
          sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the
          literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the
          knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision
          should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with
          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific
          articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These
          references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in
          formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the
          entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single,
          cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
          that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
          flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities
          into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this
          module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands
          of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring
          the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different
          complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act
          together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This
          approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate.txt
      vars: *ref_76
      response:
        output: >-
          We propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach that integrates different
          data modalities into a common representation for joint analysis. This
          method provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies, allowing
          us to infer how groups of functionally-related genes influence complex
          traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic properties among
          traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations affect genes'
          activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait
          associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples. We use a latent representation
          defined by matrix factorization that extracts gene modules with
          certain sparsity constraints and preferences for those that align with
          prior knowledge (pathways). Our results show that diseases are
          significantly associated with gene modules expressed in relevant cell
          types, such as hypothyroidism with T cells and neuropsychiatric
          disorders with different brain cell types. We also observe that
          significant module-trait associations replicate in the Electronic
          Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III, suggesting
          that our method can prioritize alternative and potentially more
          promising candidate targets even when known single gene associations
          are not detected. Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze
          lipid regulation in HepG2 cells and observe more robust trait
          associations with modules than with individual genes. Our results
          suggest that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Overall, PhenoPLIER
          represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic
          studies, providing a gene module perspective that enhances the
          understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section.


          Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
          that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
          flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities
          into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this
          module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands
          of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring
          the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different
          complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act
          together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This
          approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.

        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/baseline.txt
      vars: *ref_76
      response:
        output: >-
          In this study, we present PhenoPLIER, an innovative approach that
          integrates gene modules into genetic studies. Our method allows for
          the analysis of multiple data modalities within a single
          representation. We demonstrate that this module perspective can reveal
          how groups of functionally related genes influence complex traits,
          identify shared and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits,
          and predict how pharmacological perturbations affect gene activity to
          exert their effects. 


          To achieve this, we map gene-trait associations and drug-induced
          transcriptional responses into a common latent representation. We
          integrate thousands of gene-trait associations from TWAS in
          PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083] and transcriptional profiles
          of drugs from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049] into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples from recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]. We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). 


          We observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene
          modules expressed in relevant cell types, such as hypothyroidism with
          T cells, corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements,
          hematological assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with
          adipose tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain
          cell types. Furthermore, we demonstrate that our module-based approach
          can identify modules associated with cell types under specific stimuli
          or disease states, and replicate significant module-trait associations
          in the Electronic Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase
          III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225].


          We also performed a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in HepG2
          cells and observed more robust trait associations with modules than
          with individual genes, even when single genes known to be involved in
          lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance. Our
          module-based method also better predicted FDA-approved drug-disease
          links by capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms
          linked with the mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with
          cardiovascular traits via a known immune mechanism). This improved
          drug-disease prediction suggests that modules may provide a better
          means to examine drug-disease relationships than individual genes.


          Finally, we explored the phenotype-module space and revealed stable
          trait clusters associated with relevant tissues, including a complex
          branch involving lipids with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and
          neuropsychiatric disorders. Our approach represents a conceptual shift
          in the interpretation of genetic studies and has the potential to
          extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations to enhance
          our understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.

          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through
          gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug
          mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene
          co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of
          complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from
          the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and
          maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown
          formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure.
          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
          that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
          flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities
          into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this
          module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands
          of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring
          the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different
          complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act
          together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This
          approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.

        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate_with_metadata.txt
      vars: *ref_76
      response:
        output: >-
          We present PhenoPLIER, an approach that integrates gene expression
          data with other omnigenomic datasets to identify functional modules
          associated with genetic studies. Our method allows for a joint
          analysis of different data modalities and can infer how groups of
          functionally-related genes influence complex traits. We show that this
          module perspective can detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects, and map gene-trait
          associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common
          latent representation.


          In our work, we integrate thousands of gene-trait associations (from
          PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional
          profiles of drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049])
          into a low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data
          on tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Furthermore, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.


          Our approach has several advantages over traditional single-gene
          studies. Firstly, it improves robustness in detecting and interpreting
          genetic associations by incorporating groups of genes that act
          together to carry out different functions in specific cell types.
          Secondly, it can prioritize alternative and potentially more promising
          candidate targets even when known single gene associations are not
          detected. Finally, exploring the phenotype-module space reveals stable
          trait clusters associated with relevant tissues, including a complex
          branch involving lipids with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and
          neuropsychiatric disorders. Our work has the potential to extract
          mechanistic insight from statistical associations to enhance the
          understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.
