      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce
          jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to
          Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C)
          structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two
          sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the
          literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the
          knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision
          should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with
          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific
          articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These
          references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in
          formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the
          entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single,
          cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
          that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
          flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities
          into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this
          module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands
          of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring
          the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different
          complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act
          together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This
          approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate.txt
      vars: *ref_76
      response:
        output: >-
          We propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach that offers a gene module
          perspective for genetic studies. The flexibility of our method allows
          us to combine different data modalities into the same representation
          for joint analysis. We demonstrate that this module perspective can
          identify how groups of functionally-related genes influence complex
          traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic properties among
          traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations affect genes'
          activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait
          associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common
          latent representation by integrating thousands of gene-trait
          associations (from TWAS in PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083])
          and transcriptional profiles of drugs (from LINCS L1000
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a low-dimensional space
          learned from public gene expression data on tens of thousands of
          RNA-seq samples (recount2 [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003;
          @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). Our method uses a latent representation
          defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). We
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types, such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Our method can also identify modules associated with cell types
          under specific stimuli or disease states, which can improve robustness
          in detecting and interpreting genetic associations. Additionally, we
          perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells and
          observe more robust trait associations with modules than with
          individual genes, even when single genes known to be involved in lipid
          metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance. This suggests that
          modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease
          relationships than individual genes. Finally, we explore the
          phenotype-module space and observe stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          summary, PhenoPLIER offers a new approach to gene studies that
          considers groups of genes that act together in specific cell types.
          This method improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations and has the potential to prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known
          single-gene associations are not detected.

          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/src/llm.py
          --model ollama=mistral=7b-instruct-fp16
      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section.


          Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
          that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
          flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities
          into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this
          module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands
          of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring
          the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different
          complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act
          together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This
          approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/baseline.txt
      vars: *ref_76
      response:
        output: >-
          In this study, we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach that
          provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. Our method
          allows for integrating different data modalities into the same
          representation for joint analysis. We demonstrate that our
          module-based perspective can infer how groups of functionally related
          genes influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct
          transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict how
          pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert their
          effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and drug-induced
          transcriptional responses into a common latent representation by
          integrating thousands of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from
          PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional
          profiles of drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049])
          into a low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data
          on tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). Our
          results show that diseases are significantly associated with gene
          modules expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with
          T cells, corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements,
          hematological assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with
          adipose tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain
          cell types. Furthermore, PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, allowing for the identification of
          modules associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease
          states. Our findings replicate in the Electronic Medical Records and
          Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225], and we perform a CRISPR screen to
          analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells, observing more robust trait
          associations with modules than with individual genes. Our module-based
          approach better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). Finally, exploring the phenotype-module
          space reveals stable trait clusters associated with relevant tissues,
          including a complex branch involving lipids with cardiovascular,
          autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In summary, PhenoPLIER
          incorporates groups of genes that act together to carry out different
          functions in specific cell types, improving robustness in detecting
          and interpreting genetic associations and providing a better means to
          examine drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Our approach
          represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies
          and has the potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical
          associations to enhance our understanding of complex diseases and
          their therapeutic modalities.

          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/src/llm.py

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through
          gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug
          mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene
          co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of
          complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from
          the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and
          maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown
          formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure.
          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
          that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
          flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities
          into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this
          module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands
          of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring
          the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different
          complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act
          together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This
          approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate_with_metadata.txt
      vars: *ref_76
      response:
        output: >-
          We propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach that provides a gene
          module perspective for genetic studies. Our method integrates
          different data modalities into the same representation for joint
          analysis, allowing us to infer how groups of functionally-related
          genes influence complex traits and predict how pharmacological
          perturbations affect genes' activity.


          In this study, we map gene-trait associations and drug-induced
          transcriptional responses into a common latent representation using
          public gene expression data on tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples
          from different cell types and diseases. We use a matrix factorization
          approach to extract gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways).


          Our results show that diseases are significantly associated with gene
          modules expressed in relevant cell types, such as hypothyroidism with
          T cells and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. We also identify modules associated with cell types under
          specific stimuli or disease states, which can provide insights into
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with drug
          mechanisms.


          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells and observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes. This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes.


          In summary, our approach incorporates groups of functionally-related
          genes that act together in specific cell types to carry out different
          functions. This approach improves robustness in detecting and
          interpreting genetic associations and has the potential to extract
          mechanistic insight from statistical associations to enhance the
          understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce
          jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to
          Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C)
          structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two
          sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the
          literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the
          knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision
          should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with
          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific
          articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These
          references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in
          formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the
          entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single,
          cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
          that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
          flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities
          into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this
          module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands
          of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring
          the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different
          complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act
          together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This
          approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate.txt
      vars: *ref_76
      response:
        output: >-
          We introduce PhenoPLIER, an innovative method that combines a gene
          module perspective with omnigenic analysis for genetic studies. Our
          approach integrates multiple data modalities into a common latent
          representation to infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a low-dimensional space using thousands of gene-trait
          associations from TWAS from PhenomeXcan, transcriptional profiles of
          drugs from LINCS L1000, and public gene expression data on tens of
          thousands of RNA-seq samples from recount2. We use a latent
          representation defined by matrix factorization to extract gene modules
          with sparsity constraints and preferences for those that align with
          prior knowledge (pathways). By mapping disease-associated genes to
          this reduced expression space, we observe significant associations
          between diseases and gene modules expressed in relevant cell types.
          Furthermore, our method can identify modules associated with specific
          stimuli or disease states by leveraging models derived from large and
          heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets. We demonstrate the effectiveness of
          PhenoPLIER through replicating its findings in the Electronic Medical
          Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III, where we observe that
          significant module-trait associations in our discovery cohort
          replicated in our replication cohort. Additionally, we perform a
          CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells and find more
          robust trait associations with modules than with individual genes. Our
          approach prioritizes alternative and potentially more promising
          candidate targets even when known single gene associations are not
          detected, providing a conceptual shift in the interpretation of
          genetic studies. PhenoPLIER has the potential to enhance our
          understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities by
          extracting mechanistic insight from statistical associations.

          exec:python
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/src/llm.py
          --model ollama=mistral=7b-instruct-fp16
      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section.


          Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
          that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
          flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities
          into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this
          module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands
          of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring
          the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different
          complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act
          together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This
          approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.

          We propose PhenoPLIER, an innovative method that provides a gene
          module perspective for genetic research. Our approach is omnigenic and
          allows for the integration of multiple data modalities into a single
          representation for joint analysis. We demonstrate that this module
          perspective can identify how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect gene activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation by integrating thousands of
          gene-trait associations from TWAS in PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083] with transcriptional profiles of drugs
          from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049], and

          of thousands of RNA-seq samples from recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]. We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). We
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types, such as hypothyroidism with T cells
          and corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements. Moreover,
          we demonstrate that our method can identify modules associated with
          cell types under specific stimuli or disease states. Our approach has
          the potential to enhance robustness in detecting and interpreting
          genetic associations, and we show how it can prioritize alternative
          and potentially more promising candidate targets even when known
          single gene associations are not detected. Overall, PhenoPLIER
          represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic
          studies, with the potential to extract mechanistic insight from
          statistical associations to enhance our understanding of complex
          diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through
          gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug
          mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene
          co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of
          complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from
          the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and
          maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown
          formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure.
          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
          that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
          flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities
          into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this
          module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands
          of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring
          the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different
          complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act
          together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This
          approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.

          that provides a gene module perspective for genetic studies. Our
          method integrates different data modalities into the same

          functionally-related genes influence complex traits and predict how

          Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
          that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
          flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities
          into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this
          module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands
          of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits

          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In

          gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.

          We propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach that provides a gene
          module perspective for genetic studies. Our method allows integrating
          different data modalities into the same representation for joint
          analysis. We demonstrate that this module perspective can infer how
          groups of functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect
          shared and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and
          predict how pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to
          exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and
          drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent
          representation. For this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait
          associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction

          the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In

          carry out different functions in specific cell types. This approach
          improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.

    head:
      prompts:
        - raw: >
            You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining

        - raw: >
            You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining
            the text of a manuscript titled '{{ title }}' with keywords '{{
            keywords }}.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from
            the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and
            maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown
            formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C)
            structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or
            two sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the
            literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the
            knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision
            should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible,
            with minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to
            scientific articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original
            text. These references are crucial for academic integrity and may
            appear in formats like "[@pmid:33931583;
            @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the
            revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision, following
            the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.

              Gene networks work in context-specific ways to carry out different
              functions, and variations in these genes can alter their
              functional roles and affect disease-relevant biological processes.
              To understand how genes influence complex traits, we must
              mechanistically understand expression regulation across different
              cell types. Previous studies have described various regulatory DNA
              elements, including genetic effects on gene expression across
              different tissues. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS

              mechanisms, which are commonly dysregulated in tissue- and cell
              lineage-specific pathology.

              Context: Genes work together in context-specific networks to carry
              out different functions. Variations in these genes can change
              their functional role and, at a higher level, affect
              disease-relevant biological processes.


              Content: To understand how genes influence complex traits, it is
              necessary to mechanistically understand expression regulation
              across different cell types. Previous studies have described
              different regulatory DNA elements including genetic effects on
              gene expression across different tissues. Integrating functional
              genomics data and GWAS data has improved the identification of
              these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly
              result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology.


              Conclusion: This manuscript aims to address a knowledge gap by
              projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns
              and identifying disease etiology and drug mechanisms. By analyzing
              gene co-expression networks across different cell types, we hope
              to uncover new therapeutic targets and drug repurposing
              opportunities. Our study will contribute to the clustering of
              complex traits by integrating functional genomics data and GWAS
              data, providing a more comprehensive understanding of how genes
              influence disease-relevant biological processes.

              ---

              Context: Genes work together in context-specific networks to carry
              out different functions. 


              Content: Variations in these genes can change their functional
              role and affect disease-relevant biological processes. Determining
              how genes influence complex traits requires understanding
              expression regulation across different cell types, which should
              lead to improved treatments. Previous studies have described
              regulatory DNA elements including genetic effects on gene
              expression across different tissues. Integrating functional
              genomics data and GWAS data has improved the identification of
              transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly
              result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology.


              Conclusion: Despite previous studies describing regulatory DNA
              elements, there is still a knowledge gap regarding how these
              mechanisms influence complex traits and contribute to disease
              development. This manuscript aims to address this gap by
              investigating the role of gene expression regulation in complex
              traits and its impact on disease outcomes. By integrating
              functional genomics data and GWAS data, we hope to identify novel
              transcriptional mechanisms that can be targeted for improved
              treatments.

              Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure. This structure
              begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences (Context),
              progresses through what is known from the literature (Content),
              and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap your
              manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
              preserve the original information as much as possible, with
              minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to
              scientific articles are kept exactly as they appear in the

              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the
              revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision, following
              the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.

              **Context:** Genes work together in networks to carry out
              different functions, and variations in these genes can affect
              disease-relevant biological processes.


              **Content:** Understanding how genes influence complex traits
              requires mechanistically understanding expression regulation
              across different cell types. Previous studies have described
              different regulatory DNA elements, including genetic effects on
              gene expression across different tissues. Integrating functional
              genomics data and GWAS data has improved the identification of
              these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly
              result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology.

              associations through gene expression patterns, highlighting
              disease etiology and drug mechanisms. By integrating functional
              genomics data and GWAS data, we will identify these
              transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly
              result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology. This
              knowledge gap will lead to improved treatments for complex
              diseases.

              out different functions, and variations in these genes can change
              their functional role and affect disease-relevant biological
              processes.

              Content: Determining how genes influence complex traits requires
              understanding expression regulation across different cell types.
              Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements,
              including genetic effects on gene expression across different
              tissues. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data has
              improved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms
              that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell
              lineage-specific pathology.

              Conclusion: This manuscript addresses a knowledge gap by exploring
              the role of genes in complex traits, specifically focusing on
              expression regulation across different cell types. By integrating
              functional genomics data and GWAS data, we aim to identify
              transcriptional mechanisms that contribute to tissue- and cell
              lineage-specific pathology. Our findings have the potential to
              improve treatments for these diseases.

            namedScores: *ref_23
            text: >-
              The availability of extensive gene expression data across multiple
              tissues provides an excellent opportunity to identify biological
              processes [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
              @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. An
              effective method for achieving this is through transcription-wide
              association studies (TWAS), which integrate expression
              quantitative trait loci (eQTL) data to provide a mechanistic
              interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS aims to test whether
              perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the
              association between genetic variants and human diseases
              [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
              @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. These
              approaches have been highly successful in understanding disease
              etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] and in
              disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
              [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], as well as drug repurposing
              [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS operates at the individual
              gene level, which does not fully capture more complex interactions
              at the network level.
            prompt: >
              You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining
              the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the
              following paragraph from the Introduction section.


              Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data
              across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
              @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
              @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to
              identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide
              association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative
              trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation
              for GWAS findings. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in
              gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic
              variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly
              successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the
              transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
              disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
              [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
              [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the
              individual gene level, which does not capture more complex
              interactions at the network level.

              ---

              **Context:** Gene expression data is widely available in various
              tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
              @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9].


              **Content:** To identify biological processes from this data, a
              powerful tool is transcription-wide association study (TWAS),
              which combines expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to
              provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS tests
              whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the
              association between genetic variants and human diseases
              [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
              @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This
              approach has been highly successful in understanding disease
              etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] and in
              disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
              [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], drug repurposing
              [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS operates at the individual
              gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at
              the network level.


              **Conclusion:** Our manuscript addresses this gap by projecting
              genetic associations through gene expression patterns to identify
              disease etiology and drug mechanisms. By analyzing gene
              co-expression networks, we can gain insights into the underlying
              biological processes that mediate these associations, which may
              inform therapeutic targets and drug repurposing strategies.

              references = {
                "@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838",
                "@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6",
                "@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776",
                "@doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9",
                "@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482",
                "@doi:10.1038/ng.3506",
                "@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889",
                "@doi:10.1038/ng.3367",
                "@pmid:33931583",
                "@doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225",
                "@pmid:31036433",
                "@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w",
                "@doi:10.1038/nn.4618",
              }


              # keep only references that are present in the input (this is
              needed because

              #  references might be removed from the input in some cases)

              references = [ref for ref in references if ref in input]


              count = len([ref for ref in references if ref in output])

              return (count / len(references) > 0.50)


              ---

              Given the availability of gene expression data across multiple
              tissues, an effective approach to identify biological processes is
              transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates
              eQTLs data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS
              findings. TWAS tests whether perturbations in gene regulatory
              mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and
              human diseases, and these approaches have been highly successful
              in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level and
              in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) and drug repurposing
              tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which
              does not capture more complex interactions at the network level.
            prompt: >
              You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining
              the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the
              following paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance
              clarity, reduce jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The
              revision should adhere to Markdown formatting and follow a
              Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure. This structure
              begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences (Context),
              progresses through what is known from the literature (Content),
              and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap your
              manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
              preserve the original information as much as possible, with
              minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to
              scientific articles are kept exactly as they appear in the
              original text. These references are crucial for academic integrity
              and may appear in formats like "[@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the
              revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision, following
              the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.

              individual gene level, which does not capture more complex
              interactions at the network level.

              ---

              Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns
              highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms. This is
              particularly important when using transcription-wide association
              studies (TWAS), which integrate expression quantitative trait loci
              (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS
              findings [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
              @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. TWAS has
              been highly successful in understanding disease etiology at the
              transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] and in
              disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
              [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w]. However, TWAS works at the
              individual gene level, which does not capture more complex
              interactions at the network level. This limitation highlights the
              need for further research into gene co-expression and functional
              genomics to identify therapeutic targets and drug repurposing
              opportunities [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618].

              ---

              Given the abundance of gene expression data across various tissues
              [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
              @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], a
              highly effective strategy to identify biological processes is the
              transcription-wide association study (TWAS). TWAS integrates
              expression quantitative trait loci (eQTL) data, providing a
              mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. The approach tests
              whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the
              association between genetic variants and human diseases
              [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
              @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367].
              Successful applications of TWAS have not only shed light on
              disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also
              facilitated disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
              [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
              [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618].


              However, TWAS operates at the individual gene level, which fails
              to capture more intricate interactions at the network level.
              Therefore, there is a knowledge gap that needs to be addressed by
              exploring the use of TWAS in combination with other approaches
              that can account for network effects. This approach could
              potentially enhance our understanding of disease mechanisms and
              facilitate the discovery of new therapeutic targets.

              ---

              The extensive availability of gene expression data across multiple
              tissues provides a valuable opportunity to identify biological
              processes using transcription-wide association studies (TWAS).
              TWAS integrates quantitative trait loci (eQTL) data to provide a
              mechanistic interpretation for genome-wide association study
              (GWAS) findings. By testing whether perturbations in gene
              regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic
              variants and human diseases, TWAS has been highly successful in
              understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level
              [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]
              and in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
              [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w]. Additionally, TWAS has been
              used for drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS
              works at the individual gene level and does not capture more
              complex interactions at the network level.
            prompt: >
              You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining
              the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the
              following paragraph from the Introduction section.


              Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data
              across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
              @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
              @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to
              identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide
              association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative
              trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation
              for GWAS findings. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in
              gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic
              variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly
              successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the
              transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
              disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
              [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
              [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the
              individual gene level, which does not capture more complex
              interactions at the network level.


              Revised paragraph:
            provider: >-
              exec:python
              /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/src/llm.py
              --model ollama=mistral=7b-instruct-fp16
