              Python code returned false

              len(output.strip().split("\n")) == 1

              ---

              Given the availability of gene expression data across several
              tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
              @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], a
              useful method for identifying biological processes is the
              transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates
              expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a
              mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS tests whether
              perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the
              association between genetic variants and human diseases
              [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
              @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and
              these approaches have been highly successful in understanding
              disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] and disease-risk
              prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w].
              However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not
              capture more complex interactions at the network level. This gap
              in understanding can be addressed by combining TWAS with other
              methods such as functional genomics and gene co-expression
              analysis to identify disease-related pathways and therapeutic
              targets [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
              @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9].


              In summary, while TWAS is a valuable tool for identifying disease
              etiology at the transcriptome level, it does not capture more
              complex interactions at the network level. By combining TWAS with
              functional genomics and gene co-expression analysis, we can
              identify disease-related pathways and therapeutic targets that may
              be missed by individual gene-level analyses. This approach has the
              potential to enhance our understanding of disease mechanisms and
              drug repurposing, ultimately leading to more effective treatments
              for complex traits.
            prompt: >
              You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining
              the text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations
              through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and
              drug mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional

              repurposing, clustering of complex traits.' Your goal is to revise
              the following paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance
              clarity, reduce jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The
              revision should adhere to Markdown formatting and follow a
              Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure. This structure
              begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences (Context),
              progresses through what is known from the literature (Content),
              and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap your
              manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
              preserve the original information as much as possible, with
              minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to
              scientific articles are kept exactly as they appear in the
              original text. These references are crucial for academic integrity
              and may appear in formats like "[@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the
              revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision, following
              the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


              Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data
              across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
              @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
              @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to
              identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide
              association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative
              trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation
              for GWAS findings. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in
              gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic
              variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly
              successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the
              transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
              disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
              [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
              [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the
              individual gene level, which does not capture more complex
              interactions at the network level.

              ---

              Gene expression data is widely available across various tissues
              [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
              @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. To
              effectively identify these biological processes, a powerful tool
              is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which
              integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to
              provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS tests
              whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the
              association between genetic variants and human diseases
              [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
              @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. These
              approaches have been highly successful in understanding disease
              etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] and in
              disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
              [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], drug repurposing
              [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS operates at the individual
              gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at
              the network level.


              In summary, TWAS is a powerful tool for identifying biological
              processes from gene expression data. While it has been successful
              in disease etiology, risk prediction, and drug repurposing, its
              limitations lie in its focus on individual genes, which does not
              capture complex interactions at the network level. Future research
              should explore ways to integrate TWAS with other approaches to
              better understand these interactions and their role in disease
              development and treatment.
            prompt: >

              progresses through what is known from the literature (Content),
              and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap your
              manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)

              minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to
              scientific articles are kept exactly as they appear in the

              ---

              Gene expression data is widely available across various tissues,
              making it an effective approach to identify biological processes.
              Transcription-wide association study (TWAS) integrates eQTLs data
              and provides a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings by
              testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms
              mediate the association between genetic variants and human
              diseases. TWAS has been highly successful not only in
              understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level but also
              in disease-risk prediction, drug repurposing, and identifying
              complex interactions at the network level. However, TWAS works at
              the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex
              interactions at the network level.

              ---

              **Context:** Gene expression data is now widely available across
              various tissues, providing an opportunity to identify biological
              processes that contribute to human diseases.


              **Content:** An effective approach for this task is
              transcription-wide association studies (TWAS), which integrates
              eQTLs data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS
              findings. TWAS tests whether perturbations in gene regulatory
              mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and
              human diseases, and has been successful in understanding disease
              etiology at the transcriptome level, as well as in disease-risk
              prediction and drug repurposing tasks.


              **Conclusion:** However, TWAS works at the individual gene level,
              which does not capture more complex interactions at the network
              level. Therefore, there is a need to develop methods that can
              integrate gene expression data with other omics data to identify
              disease-associated genetic variants and therapeutic targets. Our
              manuscript aims to address this knowledge gap by developing a
              novel method that combines gene co-expression analysis with
              clustering of complex traits to identify disease etiology and drug
              mechanisms.

              ---

              Context: Gene expression data is available across various tissues,
              providing a rich source of information for studying biological
              processes.


              Content: The transcription-wide association study (TWAS) is an
              effective approach to identify these processes by integrating
              expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data. TWAS tests
              whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the
              association between genetic variants and human diseases, and has
              been highly successful in disease etiology at the transcriptome
              level as well as in disease-risk prediction, drug repurposing, and
              other related tasks.


              Conclusion: While TWAS works at the individual gene level, it does
              not capture more complex interactions at the network level.
              Therefore, there is a need to develop methods that can account for
              these interactions and provide a comprehensive understanding of
              biological processes. This manuscript aims to address this gap in
              knowledge by proposing a novel approach that integrates both
              gene-level and network-level data to identify complex interactions
              involved in disease etiology.
            prompt: >
              You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining

              revision should adhere to Markdown formatting and follow a

              progresses through what is known from the literature (Content),
              and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap your
              manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
              preserve the original information as much as possible, with

              ---

              Gene expression data is widely available across different tissues,
              providing a valuable resource for identifying biological processes
              involved in human diseases. Transcription-wide association studies
              (TWAS) leverage this information by integrating expression
              quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic
              interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS tests whether perturbations
              in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between
              genetic variants and human diseases, and these approaches have
              been highly successful in understanding disease etiology at the
              transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]. Additionally,
              TWAS has been used for disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
              [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
              [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS operates at the individual
              gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at
              the network level.
            prompt: >
              You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining
              the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the
              following paragraph from the Introduction section.


              Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data
              across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
              @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
              @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to
              identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide
              association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative
              trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation
              for GWAS findings. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in
              gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic
              variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly
              successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the
              transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
              disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
              [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
              [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the
              individual gene level, which does not capture more complex
              interactions at the network level.

                "@pmid:31036433",
                "@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w",
                "@doi:10.1038/nn.4618",
              }


              # keep only references that are present in the input (this is
              needed because

              #  references might be removed from the input in some cases)

              references = [ref for ref in references if ref in input]


              count = len([ref for ref in references if ref in output])

              return (count / len(references) > 0.50)


              ---

              Gene expression data across multiple tissues is widely available,
              and an effective approach to identify biological processes is
              transcription-wide association studies (TWAS). This method
              integrates eQTLs data to provide a mechanistic interpretation of
              GWAS findings. TWAS tests whether perturbations in gene regulatory
              mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and
              human diseases. These approaches have been highly successful in
              understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level,
              predicting disease risk (polygenic scores), and drug repurposing
              tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level and does
              not capture more complex interactions at the network level. Our
              manuscript aims to fill this gap by using gene co-expression
              analysis to identify disease etiology and drug mechanisms through
              gene expression patterns.

              progresses through what is known from the literature (Content),

              ---

              ## Context


              The availability of gene expression data across multiple tissues
              has provided a wealth of information for understanding biological
              processes and identifying disease risk factors.


              ## Content


              To effectively analyze this data, researchers have developed
              transcription-wide association studies (TWAS), which integrate
              expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a
              mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS tests whether
              perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the
              association between genetic variants and human diseases. These
              approaches have been highly successful in understanding disease
              etiology at the transcriptome level, predicting disease risk, and
              identifying drug repurposing opportunities.


              ## Conclusion


              While TWAS has provided valuable insights into complex biological
              processes, it works at the individual gene level, which does not
              capture more complex interactions at the network level. Therefore,
              there is a need for further research to develop more advanced
              methods that can account for these interactions and provide a more
              comprehensive understanding of disease mechanisms.
            prompt: >
              You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining
              the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the
              following paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance
              clarity, reduce jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The
              revision should adhere to Markdown formatting and follow a
              Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure. This structure
              begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences (Context),
              progresses through what is known from the literature (Content),
              and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap your
              manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
              preserve the original information as much as possible, with
              minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to
              scientific articles are kept exactly as they appear in the

              and may appear in formats like "[@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the
              revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision, following

              ---

              **Context:** Genetic studies have long been an important tool in
              understanding disease etiology and identifying potential
              therapeutic targets. However, these approaches often rely on
              testing for associations between genetic variants and human
              diseases, which can be challenging to interpret at the
              transcriptome level.


              **Content:** Functional genomics, such as gene co-expression
              analysis, has emerged as a powerful approach to identifying
              biological processes that underlie disease risk and drug response.
              TWAS (Transcription-wide Association Study) is one such method
              that integrates eQTLs (Expression Quantitative Trait Loci) data to
              provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. While TWAS
              has been highly successful in identifying disease risk genes, it
              does not capture more complex interactions at the network level.


              **Conclusion:** Our manuscript proposes a novel approach that
              combines gene expression patterns with network analysis to
              identify disease etiology and drug mechanisms. By clustering
              complex traits based on their genetic and functional associations,
              we hope to provide new insights into disease pathways and
              potential therapeutic targets. Our study highlights an important
              gap in the literature by integrating gene expression data with
              network analysis to capture more complex interactions at the
              network level.

              ---

              TWAS is a scientific approach that focuses on identifying
              perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms that mediate the
              association between genetic variants and human diseases. This
              method has been highly successful in understanding disease
              etiology at the transcriptome level, predicting disease risk, and
              repurposing drugs [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. However, the focus on individual genes does
              not capture more complex interactions at the network level. To
              address this gap, TWAS integrates expression quantitative trait
              loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS
              findings. This method has shown promise in identifying biological
              processes across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
              @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
              @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9].


              In summary, TWAS is a valuable tool for identifying perturbations
              in gene regulatory mechanisms that mediate the association between
              genetic variants and human diseases. While this method has been
              highly successful in understanding disease etiology, it does not
              capture more complex interactions at the network level. By
              integrating eQTLs data, TWAS provides a mechanistic interpretation
              for GWAS findings and has shown promise in identifying biological
              processes across several tissues. Further research is needed to
              fully understand the potential of TWAS and its limitations.

              ---

              ## Context


              TWAS is a powerful method used in genetic studies to investigate
              the relationship between genetic variants and human diseases. It
              relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory
              mechanisms mediate this association.


              ## Content


              The literature has shown that TWAS approaches have been highly
              successful in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome
              level, predicting disease risk (polygenic scores), and repurposing
              drugs [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
              @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
              @doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9].
              However, one limitation of TWAS is that it works at the individual
              gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at
              the network level.


              ## Conclusion


              In this manuscript, we propose a novel approach to overcome this
              limitation by integrating gene co-expression data and clustering
              of complex traits. Our method provides a mechanistic
              interpretation for GWAS findings and highlights therapeutic
              targets for drug repurposing. By combining functional genomics
              with gene expression patterns, our study sheds light on the
              etiology of diseases and opens up new avenues for drug discovery.

              network level. Therefore, there is a knowledge gap that needs to
              be addressed in order to gain a comprehensive understanding of
              disease etiology and risk prediction. Addressing this gap will
              require the development of new methods that can integrate
              network-level data into TWAS analyses.

              TWAS is a powerful tool that relies on testing whether
              perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the

              as well as identifying potential drug targets for repurposing.

              disease etiology and drug mechanisms at the network level. Our

              disease and inform the development of personalized treatments.

              begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences (Context),
              progresses through what is known from the literature (Content),
              and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap your
              manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
              preserve the original information as much as possible, with
              minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to
              scientific articles are kept exactly as they appear in the
              original text. These references are crucial for academic integrity
              and may appear in formats like "[@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the
              revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision, following
              the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.

              ---

              ## Context

              TWAS is a scientific approach that aims to understand the
              association between genetic variants and human diseases by testing
              whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate this
              relationship.


              ## Content

              The literature suggests that TWAS has been highly successful in
              disease etiology at the transcriptome level, as well as in
              disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) and drug repurposing
              tasks. One of the advantages of TWAS is the availability of gene
              expression data across several tissues, which makes it an
              effective approach to identify biological processes. However, TWAS
              works at the individual gene level, which does not capture more
              complex interactions at the network level.


              ## Conclusion

              In summary, TWAS is a valuable tool for understanding disease
              etiology and predicting disease risk, but its limitations include
              the inability to capture more complex interactions at the network
              level. Further research is needed to develop methods that can
              integrate gene expression data across tissues and provide a
              comprehensive view of disease mechanisms.

              ---

              The Transcriptomics Workbench for Associating Sequences (TWAS) is
              a powerful tool in the field of genetics and disease research. It
              relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory
              mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and
              human diseases. This approach has been highly successful in
              understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level, as well
              as in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) and drug
              repurposing tasks. The availability of gene expression data across
              several tissues provides an opportunity to identify biological
              processes using a transcription-wide association study (TWAS),
              which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data
              to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings.
              However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not
              capture more complex interactions at the network level.

              ---

              The availability of gene expression data across various tissues
              provides a valuable resource for identifying biological processes.
              Transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) can be used to
              integrate eQTLs data and provide a mechanistic interpretation for
              GWAS findings. However, TWAS operates at the individual gene
              level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the
              network level. Recent studies have shown that these approaches are
              highly successful in understanding disease etiology at the
              transcriptome level, predicting disease risk (polygenic scores),
              and repurposing drugs [@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433;
              @doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w; @doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However,
              these studies have not explored the potential for identifying
              therapeutic targets and drug mechanisms using gene co-expression
              patterns. In this manuscript, we propose a novel approach that
              leverages gene expression patterns to identify disease-associated
              genes and predict their interactions with other genes in the
              network. Our findings will provide insights into disease etiology
              and drug mechanisms, which can be used to develop new therapeutic
              strategies.

              ---

              Context: Gene expression data has become increasingly available
              across various tissues, providing a valuable resource for
              understanding biological processes at the transcriptome level.


              Content: However, traditional approaches such as
              transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) only provide a
              mechanistic interpretation of genetic variants and their
              association with diseases at the individual gene level. This
              approach does not capture more complex interactions at the network
              level. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene
              regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic
              variants and human diseases, which has been highly successful in
              disease etiology, risk prediction, drug repurposing, and other
              tasks.


              Conclusion: While TWAS is a valuable tool for understanding
              biological processes at the transcriptome level, it does not
              capture more complex interactions at the network level. Therefore,
              there is a need to develop new approaches that can provide a
              comprehensive understanding of disease etiology and risk
              prediction at the network level.

              clarity, reduce jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The
              revision should adhere to Markdown formatting and follow a
              Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure. This structure
              begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences (Context),
              progresses through what is known from the literature (Content),
              and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap your
              manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
              preserve the original information as much as possible, with
              minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to
              scientific articles are kept exactly as they appear in the
              original text. These references are crucial for academic integrity
              and may appear in formats like "[@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the
              revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision, following
              the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.

              ---

              Gene expression data is widely available across multiple tissues,
              providing a valuable resource for identifying biological processes
              associated with genetic variants and human diseases. An effective
              approach to achieve this is the transcription-wide association
              study (TWAS), which integrates eQTLs data to provide a mechanistic
              interpretation for GWAS findings. However, TWAS operates at an
              individual gene level, which does not capture more complex
              interactions at the network level. TWAS relies on testing whether
              perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the
              association between genetic variants and human diseases, and these
              approaches have been highly successful in understanding disease
              etiology at the transcriptome level, as well as in disease-risk
              prediction (polygenic scores) and drug repurposing tasks.

              ---

              Context: Gene expression data has become increasingly available
              across various tissues, providing a wealth of information for
              studying complex biological processes.


              Content: Transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) have
              emerged as an effective approach to identify gene expression
              patterns associated with genetic variants and human diseases.
              However, these studies focus on individual genes and do not
              capture the more complex interactions at the network level. TWAS
              relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory
              mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and
              diseases, which has been successful in disease etiology studies,
              risk prediction (polygenic scores), and drug repurposing tasks.


              Conclusion: While TWAS has provided valuable insights into disease
              etiology and drug mechanisms at the transcriptome level, a more
              comprehensive approach that captures network-level interactions is
              needed to fully understand the complexities of genetic
              associations with diseases. Our manuscript aims to address this
              gap by integrating gene co-expression analysis with functional
              genomics data to identify novel therapeutic targets and drug
              repurposing opportunities for various complex traits.

              ---

              **Context:** Gene expression data has been widely collected across
              various tissues, providing a wealth of information for studying
              biological processes at the transcriptome level.


              **Content:** Transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) have
              emerged as an effective approach to identify gene expression
              patterns associated with human diseases by integrating eQTLs data.
              TWAS works by testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory
              mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and
              diseases, providing a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS
              findings. However, TWAS only operates at the individual gene
              level, which fails to capture more complex interactions at the
              network level.


              **Conclusion:** While TWAS has been highly successful in
              understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level and in
              disease-risk prediction, drug repurposing, and other tasks, it
              does not account for more complex interactions within gene
              regulatory networks. Our manuscript aims to address this knowledge
              gap by developing a novel approach that integrates both gene
              expression and network data to identify disease-associated
              biological processes at the network level.

              The abundance of gene expression data across various tissues has
              facilitated the identification of biological processes through

              the association between genetic variants and human diseases

              ---

              In recent years, advances in functional genomics have provided
              gene expression data across various tissues
              [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
              @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9].
              These datasets allow researchers to identify biological processes
              associated with genetic variants, providing insight into disease
              etiology and drug mechanisms. However, existing approaches, such
              as transcription-wide association studies (TWAS), focus on
              individual genes and do not capture more complex interactions at
              the network level [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. Our manuscript proposes a novel method that
              integrates gene expression data with functional genomics
              techniques to identify genetic associations through gene
              co-expression patterns, providing a more holistic understanding of
              disease etiology and drug mechanisms [@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]. By clustering
              complex traits, our approach can identify therapeutic targets and
              drug repurposing opportunities [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w].
              Our study addresses a gap in the literature by providing a more
              comprehensive understanding of disease etiology and drug
              mechanisms through gene co-expression analysis, which has not been
              extensively explored before.

              Given the widespread availability of gene expression data across

              [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;

              more complex interactions at the network level. Therefore, this
              study aims to address this knowledge gap by developing a novel

              analysis techniques to identify biological processes associated

              clarity, reduce jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The

              Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure. This structure
              begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences (Context),
              progresses through what is known from the literature (Content),
              and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap your
              manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
              preserve the original information as much as possible, with
              minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to
              scientific articles are kept exactly as they appear in the
              original text. These references are crucial for academic integrity
              and may appear in formats like "[@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the
              revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision, following
              the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


              Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data
              across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
              @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
              @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to
              identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide
              association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative
              trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation
              for GWAS findings. However, TWAS works at the individual gene
              level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the
              network level. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in

              The availability of gene expression data across multiple tissues
              offers an effective approach to identify biological processes.
              Transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) can be used to
              integrate expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data and
              provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings at the
              individual gene level. However, TWAS does not capture more complex
              interactions at the network level. In order to understand disease
              etiology at the transcriptome level, approaches such as testing
              whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the
              association between genetic variants and human diseases have been
              highly successful [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;

              ---

              Context: Gene expression data are increasingly available across
              various tissues, providing valuable insights into the molecular
              mechanisms underlying human diseases. However, these datasets
              often contain complex interactions between genes that cannot be
              fully captured by analyzing individual gene expression patterns.


              Content: Functional genomics approaches, such as
              transcription-wide association studies (TWAS), have been
              successful in identifying genetic associations with disease
              etiology and drug mechanisms at the transcriptome level. TWAS
              integrates eQTLs data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for
              GWAS findings, allowing researchers to test whether perturbations
              in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between
              genetic variants and human diseases.


              Conclusion: While TWAS has been successful in understanding
              disease etiology at the transcriptome level and predicting disease
              risk through polygenic scores, it does not capture more complex
              interactions at the network level. Our manuscript aims to address
              this gap by projecting genetic associations through gene
              expression patterns, highlighting disease etiology and drug
              mechanisms at a systems level. By leveraging clustering of complex
              traits, we aim to uncover novel therapeutic targets for diseases
              that are not well understood or have limited treatment options.

              transcription-wide association studies (TWAS), which integrate
              expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a

              does not capture more complex interactions at the network level.

              The availability of gene expression data across multiple tissues
              has provided an opportunity to identify biological processes using
              transcription-wide association studies (TWAS). TWAS integrates
              expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a
              mechanistic interpretation for genetic variants associated with
              human diseases. However, TWAS operates at the individual gene
              level and does not capture more complex interactions at the
              network level.

              mediate the association between genetic variants and human
              diseases. These approaches have been highly successful in

              tissues provides a valuable resource for identifying biological
              processes related to human diseases. However, traditional
              approaches like transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) only
              focus on individual genes and do not capture the complexity of
              interactions at the network level.

              interpretation for GWAS findings, but it works at the individual
              gene level. This approach has been highly successful in

              tasks.

              genetic associations through gene expression patterns, which
              highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms at a network

              have been captured by traditional approaches. This will provide
              new insights into the underlying mechanisms of human diseases and
              lead to the discovery of novel therapeutic targets.

            @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an
            effective approach to identify these biological processes is the
            transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates
            expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a
            mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. However, TWAS works at
            the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex
            interactions at the network level. TWAS relies on testing whether
            perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association
            between genetic variants and human diseases
            [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
            @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these
            approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding
            disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
            @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
            disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
            [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
            [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks.
          - >-
            genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression,
            therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits
          - ends with conclusion
          - >-
            Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns
            highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms
      - outputs:
          - pass: false
            score: 0.8571428571428571
            namedScores: *ref_75
            text: >-
              Python code returned false

              len(output.strip().split("\n")) == 1

              ---

              In this manuscript, we present PhenoPLIER, an innovative approach
              that integrates gene modules into genetic studies. By combining
              different data modalities into a single representation, our method
              enables joint analysis of complex traits and allows for the
              discovery of shared and distinct transcriptomic properties among
              them. We demonstrate how PhenoPLIER can infer how groups of
              functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect
              drug-induced transcriptional responses, and predict their effects
              on gene activity to exert therapeutic outcomes. 


              To achieve this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait associations
              (from TWAS in PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and
              transcriptional profiles of drugs (from LINCS L1000
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a low-dimensional space
              learned from public gene expression data on tens of thousands of
              RNA-seq samples (recount2 [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003;
              @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a latent representation defined by
              matrix factorization approaches that extract gene modules with
              specific sparsity constraints and preferences for those that align
              with prior knowledge (pathways). Our results show that diseases
              are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in
              relevant cell types, such as hypothyroidism with T cells or
              corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements.
              Furthermore, we observe that significant module-trait associations
              in PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic
              Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III (our
              replication cohort). 


              Our approach also demonstrates improved drug-disease prediction by
              capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked
              with the mechanism of action of drugs. For instance, we observe
              that niacin is associated with cardiovascular traits via an immune
              mechanism in liver cells. Compared to a single-gene approach, our
              module-based method also better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease
              links by capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms
              linked with the mechanism of action of drugs. 


              Finally, exploring the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait
              clusters associated with relevant tissues, including a complex
              branch involving lipids with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and
              neuropsychiatric disorders. In summary, PhenoPLIER incorporates
              groups of genes that act together to carry out different functions
              in specific cell types, which improves robustness in detecting and
              interpreting genetic associations and prioritizes alternative and
              potentially more promising candidate targets even when known
              single gene associations are not detected. Our approach represents
              a conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies and
              has the potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical
              associations to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and
              their therapeutic modalities.
            prompt: >
              You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining
              the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the
              following paragraph from the Introduction section.


              Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
              that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
              flexibility of our method allows integrating different data
              modalities into the same representation for a joint analysis. We
              show that this module perspective can infer how groups of
              functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect shared
              and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict
              how pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert
              their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and
              drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent
              representation. For this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait
              associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
              [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of
              drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
              low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on
              tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use
              a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
              [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003]
              that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
              preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways).
              When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression
              space, we observe that diseases are significantly associated with
              gene modules expressed in relevant cell types: such as
              hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with
              keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood
              cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and
              neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types.
              Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large and
              heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
              associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease
              states. We observe that significant module-trait associations in
              PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic
              Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III
              [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our
              replication cohort). Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to
              analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust
              trait associations with modules than with individual genes, even
              when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not
              reach genome-wide significance. Compared to a single-gene
              approach, our module-based method also better predicts
              FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific
              pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action
              of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known
              immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests
              that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease
              relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the
              phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
              with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
              with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders.
              In summary, instead of considering single genes associated with
              different complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes
              that act together to carry out different functions in specific
              cell types. This approach improves robustness in detecting and
              interpreting genetic associations, and here we show how it can
              prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate
              targets even when known single gene associations are not detected.
              The approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation
              of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract mechanistic
              insight from statistical associations to enhance the understanding
              of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

              We propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach that provides a gene
              module perspective for genetic studies. Our method allows
              integrating different data modalities into the same representation
              for joint analysis. We show that this module perspective can infer
              how groups of functionally-related genes influence complex traits,
              detect shared and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits,
              and predict how pharmacological perturbations affect genes'
              activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait
              associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses into a
              common latent representation by integrating thousands of
              gene-trait associations (from TWAS from PhenomeXcan
              [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of
              drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
              low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on
              tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use
              a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
              [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003]
              that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
              preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways).
              We observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene
              modules expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism
              with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with keratometry
              measurements, hematological assays on specific blood cell types,
              plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders
              with different brain cell types. Moreover, PhenoPLIER can use
              models derived from large and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets to
              identify modules associated with cell types under specific stimuli
              or disease states. We observe that significant module-trait
              associations in PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in
              the Electronic Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase
              III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225]
              (our replication cohort). Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen
              to analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells and observe more robust
              trait associations with modules than with individual genes, even
              when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not
              reach genome-wide significance. Compared to a single-gene
              approach, our module-based method also better predicts
              FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific
              pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action
              of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known
              immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests
              that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease
              relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the
              phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
              with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
              with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders.
              In summary, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act
              together to carry out different functions in specific cell types,
              improving robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
              associations and prioritizing alternative and potentially more
              promising candidate targets even when known single gene
              associations are not detected. This approach represents a
              conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies, with
              the potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical
              associations to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and
              their therapeutic modalities.

              that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
              flexibility of our method allows integrating different data

              and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict
              how pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert
              their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and
              drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent
              representation. For this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait
              associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
              [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of
              drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
              low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on
              tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use
              a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
              [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003]
              that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
              preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways).
              When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression
              space, we observe that diseases are significantly associated with

              hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with
              keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood
              cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and
              neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types.

              heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
              associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease
              states. We observe that significant module-trait associations in
              PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic
              Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III
              [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our
              replication cohort). Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to
              analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust
              trait associations with modules than with individual genes, even
              when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not

              relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the

              with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
              with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders.

              that act together to carry out different functions in specific
              cell types. This approach improves robustness in detecting and
              interpreting genetic associations, and here we show how it can
              prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate
              targets even when known single gene associations are not detected.
              The approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation
              of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract mechanistic
              insight from statistical associations to enhance the understanding
              of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

              ---

              Context: Genetic studies have traditionally focused on single
              genes, but recent advances in technology and methodology have
              enabled a more holistic approach to understanding gene function
              and disease mechanisms. 

              Content: PhenoPLIER is an omnigenic method that integrates
              different data modalities into a common latent representation for
              joint analysis. This module perspective allows for the inference
              of how groups of functionally-related genes influence complex
              traits, detection of shared and distinct transcriptomic properties
              among traits, and prediction of how pharmacological perturbations
              affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
              gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
              into a low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression
              data on tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples. The method uses a
              latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
              that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
              preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). 

              Conclusion: PhenoPLIER's module perspective provides a more robust
              and interpretable approach to genetic studies. By analyzing groups
              of genes that act together in specific cell types, PhenoPLIER
              improves the detection and interpretation of genetic associations.
              The method can prioritize alternative and potentially more
              promising candidate targets even when known single gene
              associations are not detected. Furthermore, PhenoPLIER's
              drug-disease prediction suggests that modules may provide a better
              means to examine drug-disease relationships than individual genes.
              Overall, PhenoPLIER represents a conceptual shift in the
              interpretation of genetic studies and has the potential to enhance
              our understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
              modalities.

              You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining
              the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the
              following paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance
              clarity, reduce jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The
              revision should adhere to Markdown formatting and follow a
              Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure. This structure
              begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences (Context),
              progresses through what is known from the literature (Content),
              and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap your
              manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
              preserve the original information as much as possible, with
              minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to
              scientific articles are kept exactly as they appear in the

              and may appear in formats like "[@pmid:33931583;

              revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision, following

              Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
              that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
              flexibility of our method allows integrating different data
              modalities into the same representation for a joint analysis. We
              show that this module perspective can infer how groups of
              functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect shared
              and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict
              how pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert
              their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and
              drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent
              representation. For this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait
              associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
              [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of
              drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
              low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on
              tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use
              a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
              [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003]
              that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
              preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways).
              When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression
              space, we observe that diseases are significantly associated with
              gene modules expressed in relevant cell types: such as
              hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with
              keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood
              cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and
              neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types.
              Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large and
              heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
              associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease
              states. We observe that significant module-trait associations in
              PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic
              Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III
              [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our
              replication cohort). Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to
              analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust
              trait associations with modules than with individual genes, even
              when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not
              reach genome-wide significance. Compared to a single-gene
              approach, our module-based method also better predicts
              FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific
              pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action
              of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known
              immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests
              that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease
              relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the
              phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
              with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
              with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders.
              In summary, instead of considering single genes associated with
              different complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes
              that act together to carry out different functions in specific
              cell types. This approach improves robustness in detecting and
              interpreting genetic associations, and here we show how it can
              prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate
              targets even when known single gene associations are not detected.
              The approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation
              of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract mechanistic
              insight from statistical associations to enhance the understanding
              of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

            Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach that provides a
            gene module perspective to genetic studies. The flexibility of our
            method allows integrating different data modalities into the same
            representation for a joint analysis. We show that this module
            perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
            influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
            properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological
            perturbations affect genes' activity to exert their effects.
            PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and drug-induced
            transcriptional responses into a common latent representation. For
            this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait associations (using TWAS
            from PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional
            profiles of drugs (from LINCS L1000
            [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a low-dimensional space
            learned from public gene expression data on tens of thousands of
            RNA-seq samples (recount2 [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003;
            @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a latent representation defined by a
            matrix factorization approach [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1;
            @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that extracts gene modules with
            certain sparsity constraints and preferences for those that align
            with prior knowledge (pathways). When mapping gene-trait
            associations to this reduced expression space, we observe that
            diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in
            relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal
            endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
            assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
            tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
            types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
            and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
            associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
            We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
            (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
            and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
            @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
            Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation
            in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with
            modules than with individual genes, even when single genes known to
            be involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide
            significance. Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based
            method also better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by
            capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with
            the mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular
            traits via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease
            prediction suggests that modules may provide a better means to
            examine drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally,
            exploring the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters
            associated with relevant tissues, including a complex branch
            involving lipids with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and
            neuropsychiatric disorders. In summary, instead of considering
            single genes associated with different complex traits, PhenoPLIER
            incorporates groups of genes that act together to carry out
            different functions in specific cell types. This approach improves
            robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic associations, and
            here we show how it can prioritize alternative and potentially more
            promising candidate targets even when known single gene associations
            are not detected. The approach represents a conceptual shift in the
            interpretation of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract
            mechanistic insight from statistical associations to enhance the
            understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.
