      - outputs:
          - pass: false
            score: 0.8571428571428571
            namedScores: *ref_80
            text: >-
              Python code returned false

              len(output.strip().split("\n")) == 1

              ---

              In this manuscript, we propose PhenoPLIER, an innovative method
              that integrates gene-trait associations and drug-induced
              transcriptional responses into a common latent representation to
              provide a gene module perspective for genetic studies. Our
              approach is omnigenic and can integrate different data modalities
              into the same representation for joint analysis. We demonstrate
              that PhenoPLIER can infer how groups of functionally related genes
              influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct
              transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict how
              pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert
              their effects.


              To achieve this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait associations
              (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and
              transcriptional profiles of drugs (from LINCS L1000
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a low-dimensional space
              learned from public gene expression data on tens of thousands of
              RNA-seq samples (recount2 [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003;
              @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a matrix factorization approach
              [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003]
              to extract gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
              preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways).
              We observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene
              modules expressed in relevant cell types, such as hypothyroidism
              with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with keratometry
              measurements, hematological assays on specific blood cell types,
              plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders
              with different brain cell types.


              Our approach can also use models derived from large and
              heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets to identify modules associated with
              cell types under specific stimuli or disease states. We observe
              that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan (our
              discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records and
              Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
              Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid
              regulation in HepG2 cells and observe more robust trait
              associations with modules than with individual genes, even when
              single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not
              reach genome-wide significance. This improved drug-disease
              prediction suggests that modules may provide a better means to
              examine drug-disease relationships than individual genes.


              Finally, exploring the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait
              clusters associated with relevant tissues, including a complex
              branch involving lipids with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and
              neuropsychiatric disorders. In summary, PhenoPLIER incorporates
              groups of genes that act together to carry out different functions
              in specific cell types, improving robustness in detecting and
              interpreting genetic associations and providing a better means to
              prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate
              targets even when known single gene associations are not detected.
              Our approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation
              of genetic studies and has the potential to extract mechanistic
              insight from statistical associations to enhance our understanding
              of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.
            prompt: >
              You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining
              the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the
              following paragraph from the Introduction section.


              Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
              that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
              flexibility of our method allows integrating different data
              modalities into the same representation for a joint analysis. We
              show that this module perspective can infer how groups of
              functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect shared
              and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict
              how pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert
              their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and
              drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent
              representation. For this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait
              associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
              [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of
              drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
              low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on
              tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use
              a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
              [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003]
              that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
              preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways).
              When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression
              space, we observe that diseases are significantly associated with
              gene modules expressed in relevant cell types: such as
              hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with
              keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood
              cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and
              neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types.
              Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large and
              heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
              associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease
              states. We observe that significant module-trait associations in
              PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic
              Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III
              [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our
              replication cohort). Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to
              analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust
              trait associations with modules than with individual genes, even
              when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not
              reach genome-wide significance. Compared to a single-gene
              approach, our module-based method also better predicts
              FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific
              pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action
              of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known
              immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests
              that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease
              relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the
              phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
              with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
              with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders.
              In summary, instead of considering single genes associated with
              different complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes
              that act together to carry out different functions in specific
              cell types. This approach improves robustness in detecting and
              interpreting genetic associations, and here we show how it can
              prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate
              targets even when known single gene associations are not detected.
              The approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation
              of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract mechanistic
              insight from statistical associations to enhance the understanding
              of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

            text: >-
              Python code returned false

              len(output.strip().split("\n")) == 1

              ---

              We propose an omnigenic approach called PhenoPLIER that integrates
              gene expression data with other types of molecular and clinical
              data to study genetic associations and drug mechanisms. Our method
              allows for a joint analysis of multiple data modalities, including
              genomic, transcriptomic, epigenomic, and clinical data, into a
              common latent space. We show that this module perspective can
              identify functional relationships between genes and complex
              traits, detect shared and distinct molecular properties among
              traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations affect gene
              activity to exert their effects.


              To achieve these goals, we integrate thousands of gene-trait
              associations from TWAS in PhenomeXcan with transcriptional
              profiles of drugs from LINCS L1000 into a low-dimensional space
              learned from public gene expression data on tens of thousands of
              RNA-seq samples. We use a latent representation defined by matrix
              factorization that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity
              constraints and preferences for those that align with prior
              knowledge (pathways). When mapping gene-trait associations to this
              reduced expression space, we observe significant correlations
              between diseases and gene modules expressed in relevant cell
              types.


              We also show that PhenoPLIER can identify modules associated with
              cell types under specific stimuli or disease states. Our approach
              has the potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical
              associations to enhance our understanding of complex diseases and
              their therapeutic modalities. For example, we observe that
              significant module-trait associations in our discovery cohort
              replicated in the Electronic Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE)
              network phase III, suggesting that modules may provide a better
              means to examine drug-disease relationships than individual genes.
              Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid
              regulation in HepG2 cells and observe more robust trait
              associations with modules than with individual genes, even when
              single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not
              reach genome-wide significance.


              In conclusion, our omnigenic approach can prioritize alternative
              and potentially more promising candidate targets even when known
              single gene associations are not detected, providing a conceptual
              shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. PhenoPLIER has the
              potential to improve robustness in detecting and interpreting
              genetic associations, and its ability to integrate multiple data
              modalities makes it a valuable tool for drug discovery and
              precision medicine.
            prompt: >
              You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining
              the text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations
              through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and
              drug mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional
              genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug
              repurposing, clustering of complex traits.' Your goal is to revise
              the following paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance
              clarity, reduce jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The
              revision should adhere to Markdown formatting and follow a
              Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure. This structure
              begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences (Context),
              progresses through what is known from the literature (Content),
              and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap your
              manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
              preserve the original information as much as possible, with
              minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to
              scientific articles are kept exactly as they appear in the
              original text. These references are crucial for academic integrity
              and may appear in formats like "[@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the
              revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision, following
              the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


              Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
              that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
              flexibility of our method allows integrating different data
              modalities into the same representation for a joint analysis. We
              show that this module perspective can infer how groups of
              functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect shared
              and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict
              how pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert
              their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and
              drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent
              representation. For this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait
              associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
              [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of
              drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
              low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on
              tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use
              a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
              [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003]
              that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
              preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways).
              When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression
              space, we observe that diseases are significantly associated with
              gene modules expressed in relevant cell types: such as
              hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with
              keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood
              cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and
              neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types.
              Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large and
              heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
              associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease
              states. We observe that significant module-trait associations in
              PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic
              Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III
              [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our
              replication cohort). Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to
              analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust
              trait associations with modules than with individual genes, even
              when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not
              reach genome-wide significance. Compared to a single-gene
              approach, our module-based method also better predicts
              FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific
              pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action
              of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known
              immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests
              that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease
              relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the
              phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
              with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
              with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders.
              In summary, instead of considering single genes associated with
              different complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes
              that act together to carry out different functions in specific
              cell types. This approach improves robustness in detecting and
              interpreting genetic associations, and here we show how it can
              prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate
              targets even when known single gene associations are not detected.
              The approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation
              of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract mechanistic
              insight from statistical associations to enhance the understanding
              of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

            text: >-
              We propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach that integrates
              different data modalities into a common representation for joint
              analysis. This method provides a gene module perspective to
              genetic studies, allowing us to infer how groups of
              functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect shared
              and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict
              how pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert
              their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and
              drug-induced transcriptional responses into a low-dimensional
              space learned from public gene expression data on tens of
              thousands of RNA-seq samples. We use a latent representation
              defined by matrix factorization that extracts gene modules with
              certain sparsity constraints and preferences for those that align
              with prior knowledge (pathways). Our results show that diseases
              are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in
              relevant cell types, such as hypothyroidism with T cells and
              neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types. We
              also observe that significant module-trait associations replicate
              in the Electronic Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network
              phase III, suggesting that our method can prioritize alternative
              and potentially more promising candidate targets even when known
              single gene associations are not detected. Furthermore, we perform
              a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells and
              observe more robust trait associations with modules than with
              individual genes. Our results suggest that modules may provide a
              better means to examine drug-disease relationships than individual
              genes. Overall, PhenoPLIER represents a conceptual shift in the
              interpretation of genetic studies, providing a gene module
              perspective that enhances the understanding of complex diseases
              and their therapeutic modalities.
            prompt: >
              You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining
              the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the
              following paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance
              clarity, reduce jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The
              revision should adhere to Markdown formatting and follow a
              Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure. This structure
              begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences (Context),
              progresses through what is known from the literature (Content),
              and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap your
              manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
              preserve the original information as much as possible, with
              minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to
              scientific articles are kept exactly as they appear in the
              original text. These references are crucial for academic integrity
              and may appear in formats like "[@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the
              revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision, following
              the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


              Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
              that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
              flexibility of our method allows integrating different data
              modalities into the same representation for a joint analysis. We
              show that this module perspective can infer how groups of
              functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect shared
              and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict
              how pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert
              their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and
              drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent
              representation. For this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait
              associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
              [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of
              drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
              low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on
              tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use
              a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
              [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003]
              that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
              preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways).
              When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression
              space, we observe that diseases are significantly associated with
              gene modules expressed in relevant cell types: such as
              hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with
              keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood
              cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and
              neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types.
              Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large and
              heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
              associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease
              states. We observe that significant module-trait associations in
              PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic
              Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III
              [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our
              replication cohort). Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to
              analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust
              trait associations with modules than with individual genes, even
              when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not
              reach genome-wide significance. Compared to a single-gene
              approach, our module-based method also better predicts
              FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific
              pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action
              of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known
              immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests
              that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease
              relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the
              phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
              with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
              with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders.
              In summary, instead of considering single genes associated with
              different complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes
              that act together to carry out different functions in specific
              cell types. This approach improves robustness in detecting and
              interpreting genetic associations, and here we show how it can
              prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate
              targets even when known single gene associations are not detected.
              The approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation
              of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract mechanistic
              insight from statistical associations to enhance the understanding
              of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

            Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach that provides a
            gene module perspective to genetic studies. The flexibility of our
            method allows integrating different data modalities into the same
            representation for a joint analysis. We show that this module
            perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
            influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
            properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological
            perturbations affect genes' activity to exert their effects.
            PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and drug-induced
            transcriptional responses into a common latent representation. For
            this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait associations (using TWAS
            from PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional
            profiles of drugs (from LINCS L1000
            [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a low-dimensional space
            learned from public gene expression data on tens of thousands of
            RNA-seq samples (recount2 [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003;
            @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a latent representation defined by a
            matrix factorization approach [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1;
            @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that extracts gene modules with
            certain sparsity constraints and preferences for those that align
            with prior knowledge (pathways). When mapping gene-trait
            associations to this reduced expression space, we observe that
            diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in
            relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal
            endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
            assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
            tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
            types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
            and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
            associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
            We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
            (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
            and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
            @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
            Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation
            in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with
            modules than with individual genes, even when single genes known to
            be involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide
            significance. Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based
            method also better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by
            capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with
            the mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular
            traits via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease
            prediction suggests that modules may provide a better means to
            examine drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally,
            exploring the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters
            associated with relevant tissues, including a complex branch
            involving lipids with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and
            neuropsychiatric disorders. In summary, instead of considering
            single genes associated with different complex traits, PhenoPLIER
            incorporates groups of genes that act together to carry out
            different functions in specific cell types. This approach improves
            robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic associations, and
            here we show how it can prioritize alternative and potentially more
            promising candidate targets even when known single gene associations
            are not detected. The approach represents a conceptual shift in the
            interpretation of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract
            mechanistic insight from statistical associations to enhance the
            understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

            genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression,
            therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits
          - has proper last paragraph structure

          - pass: false
            score: 0.8571428571428571
            namedScores: *ref_83
            text: >-
              Python code returned false

              len(output.strip().split("\n")) == 1

              ---

              In this study, we present PhenoPLIER, an innovative approach that
              integrates gene modules into genetic studies. Our method allows
              for the analysis of multiple data modalities within a single
              representation. We demonstrate that this module perspective can
              reveal how groups of functionally related genes influence complex
              traits, identify shared and distinct transcriptomic properties
              among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations affect
              gene activity to exert their effects. 


              To achieve this, we map gene-trait associations and drug-induced
              transcriptional responses into a common latent representation. We
              integrate thousands of gene-trait associations from TWAS in
              PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083] and transcriptional
              profiles of drugs from LINCS L1000
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049] into a low-dimensional space
              learned from public gene expression data on tens of thousands of
              RNA-seq samples from recount2 [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003;
              @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]. We use a latent representation defined by
              a matrix factorization approach [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1;
              @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that extracts gene modules with
              certain sparsity constraints and preferences for those that align
              with prior knowledge (pathways). 


              We observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene
              modules expressed in relevant cell types, such as hypothyroidism
              with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with keratometry
              measurements, hematological assays on specific blood cell types,
              plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders
              with different brain cell types. Furthermore, we demonstrate that
              our module-based approach can identify modules associated with
              cell types under specific stimuli or disease states, and replicate
              significant module-trait associations in the Electronic Medical
              Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III
              [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225].


              We also performed a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
              HepG2 cells and observed more robust trait associations with
              modules than with individual genes, even when single genes known
              to be involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide
              significance. Our module-based method also better predicted
              FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific
              pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action
              of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known
              immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests
              that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease
              relationships than individual genes.


              Finally, we explored the phenotype-module space and revealed
              stable trait clusters associated with relevant tissues, including
              a complex branch involving lipids with cardiovascular, autoimmune,
              and neuropsychiatric disorders. Our approach represents a
              conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies and has
              the potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical
              associations to enhance our understanding of complex diseases and
              their therapeutic modalities.
            prompt: >
              You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining
              the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the
              following paragraph from the Introduction section.


              Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
              that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
              flexibility of our method allows integrating different data
              modalities into the same representation for a joint analysis. We
              show that this module perspective can infer how groups of
              functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect shared
              and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict
              how pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert
              their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and
              drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent
              representation. For this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait
              associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
              [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of
              drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
              low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on
              tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use
              a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
              [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003]
              that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
              preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways).
              When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression
              space, we observe that diseases are significantly associated with
              gene modules expressed in relevant cell types: such as
              hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with
              keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood
              cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and
              neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types.
              Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large and
              heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
              associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease
              states. We observe that significant module-trait associations in
              PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic
              Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III
              [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our
              replication cohort). Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to
              analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust
              trait associations with modules than with individual genes, even
              when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not
              reach genome-wide significance. Compared to a single-gene
              approach, our module-based method also better predicts
              FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific
              pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action
              of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known
              immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests
              that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease
              relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the
              phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
              with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
              with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders.
              In summary, instead of considering single genes associated with
              different complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes
              that act together to carry out different functions in specific
              cell types. This approach improves robustness in detecting and
              interpreting genetic associations, and here we show how it can
              prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate
              targets even when known single gene associations are not detected.
              The approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation
              of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract mechanistic
              insight from statistical associations to enhance the understanding
              of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

            text: >-
              Python code returned false

              len(output.strip().split("\n")) == 1

              ---

              We present PhenoPLIER, an approach that integrates gene expression
              data with other omnigenomic datasets to identify functional
              modules associated with genetic studies. Our method allows for a
              joint analysis of different data modalities and can infer how
              groups of functionally-related genes influence complex traits. We
              show that this module perspective can detect shared and distinct
              transcriptomic properties among traits, predict how
              pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert
              their effects, and map gene-trait associations and drug-induced
              transcriptional responses into a common latent representation.


              In our work, we integrate thousands of gene-trait associations
              (from PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and
              transcriptional profiles of drugs (from LINCS L1000
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a low-dimensional space
              learned from public gene expression data on tens of thousands of
              RNA-seq samples (recount2 [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003;
              @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a latent representation defined by
              a matrix factorization approach [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1;
              @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that extracts gene modules with
              certain sparsity constraints and preferences for those that align
              with prior knowledge (pathways). When mapping gene-trait
              associations to this reduced expression space, we observe that
              diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed
              in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
              corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements,
              hematological assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids
              with adipose tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different
              brain cell types. Furthermore, since PhenoPLIER can use models
              derived from large and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also
              identify modules associated with cell types under specific stimuli
              or disease states.


              Our approach has several advantages over traditional single-gene
              studies. Firstly, it improves robustness in detecting and
              interpreting genetic associations by incorporating groups of genes
              that act together to carry out different functions in specific
              cell types. Secondly, it can prioritize alternative and
              potentially more promising candidate targets even when known
              single gene associations are not detected. Finally, exploring the
              phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
              with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
              with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders.
              Our work has the potential to extract mechanistic insight from
              statistical associations to enhance the understanding of complex
              diseases and their therapeutic modalities.
            prompt: >
              You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining
              the text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations
              through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and
              drug mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional
              genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug
              repurposing, clustering of complex traits.' Your goal is to revise
              the following paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance
              clarity, reduce jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The
              revision should adhere to Markdown formatting and follow a
              Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure. This structure
              begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences (Context),
              progresses through what is known from the literature (Content),
              and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap your
              manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
              preserve the original information as much as possible, with
              minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to
              scientific articles are kept exactly as they appear in the
              original text. These references are crucial for academic integrity
              and may appear in formats like "[@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the
              revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision, following
              the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


              Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
              that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
              flexibility of our method allows integrating different data
              modalities into the same representation for a joint analysis. We
              show that this module perspective can infer how groups of
              functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect shared
              and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict
              how pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert
              their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and
              drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent
              representation. For this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait
              associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
              [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of
              drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
              low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on
              tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use
              a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
              [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003]
              that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
              preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways).
              When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression
              space, we observe that diseases are significantly associated with
              gene modules expressed in relevant cell types: such as
              hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with
              keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood
              cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and
              neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types.
              Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large and
              heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
              associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease
              states. We observe that significant module-trait associations in
              PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic
              Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III
              [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our
              replication cohort). Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to
              analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust
              trait associations with modules than with individual genes, even
              when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not
              reach genome-wide significance. Compared to a single-gene
              approach, our module-based method also better predicts
              FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific
              pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action
              of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known
              immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests
              that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease
              relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the
              phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
              with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
              with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders.
              In summary, instead of considering single genes associated with
              different complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes
              that act together to carry out different functions in specific
              cell types. This approach improves robustness in detecting and
              interpreting genetic associations, and here we show how it can
              prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate
              targets even when known single gene associations are not detected.
              The approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation
              of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract mechanistic
              insight from statistical associations to enhance the understanding
              of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

            text: >-
              We propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach that offers a gene
              module perspective for genetic studies. The flexibility of our
              method allows us to combine different data modalities into the
              same representation for joint analysis. We demonstrate that this
              module perspective can identify how groups of functionally-related
              genes influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct
              transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict how
              pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert
              their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and
              drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent
              representation by integrating thousands of gene-trait associations
              (from TWAS in PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and
              transcriptional profiles of drugs (from LINCS L1000
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a low-dimensional space
              learned from public gene expression data on tens of thousands of
              RNA-seq samples (recount2 [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003;
              @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). Our method uses a latent representation
              defined by a matrix factorization approach
              [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003]
              that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
              preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways).
              We observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene
              modules expressed in relevant cell types, such as hypothyroidism
              with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with keratometry
              measurements, hematological assays on specific blood cell types,
              plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders
              with different brain cell types. Our method can also identify
              modules associated with cell types under specific stimuli or
              disease states, which can improve robustness in detecting and
              interpreting genetic associations. Additionally, we perform a
              CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells and
              observe more robust trait associations with modules than with
              individual genes, even when single genes known to be involved in
              lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance. This
              suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
              drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, we
              explore the phenotype-module space and observe stable trait
              clusters associated with relevant tissues, including a complex
              branch involving lipids with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and
              neuropsychiatric disorders. In summary, PhenoPLIER offers a new
              approach to gene studies that considers groups of genes that act
              together in specific cell types. This method improves robustness
              in detecting and interpreting genetic associations and has the
              potential to prioritize alternative and potentially more promising
              candidate targets even when known single-gene associations are not
              detected.

              You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining
              the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the
              following paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance
              clarity, reduce jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The
              revision should adhere to Markdown formatting and follow a
              Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure. This structure
              begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences (Context),
              progresses through what is known from the literature (Content),
              and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap your
              manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
              preserve the original information as much as possible, with
              minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to
              scientific articles are kept exactly as they appear in the
              original text. These references are crucial for academic integrity
              and may appear in formats like "[@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the
              revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision, following
              the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


              Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
              that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
              flexibility of our method allows integrating different data
              modalities into the same representation for a joint analysis. We
              show that this module perspective can infer how groups of
              functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect shared
              and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict
              how pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert
              their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and
              drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent
              representation. For this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait
              associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
              [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of
              drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
              low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on
              tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use
              a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
              [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003]
              that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
              preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways).
              When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression
              space, we observe that diseases are significantly associated with
              gene modules expressed in relevant cell types: such as
              hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with
              keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood
              cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and
              neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types.
              Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large and
              heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
              associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease
              states. We observe that significant module-trait associations in
              PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic
              Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III
              [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our
              replication cohort). Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to
              analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust
              trait associations with modules than with individual genes, even
              when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not
              reach genome-wide significance. Compared to a single-gene
              approach, our module-based method also better predicts
              FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific
              pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action
              of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known
              immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests
              that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease
              relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the
              phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
              with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
              with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders.
              In summary, instead of considering single genes associated with
              different complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes
              that act together to carry out different functions in specific
              cell types. This approach improves robustness in detecting and
              interpreting genetic associations, and here we show how it can
              prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate
              targets even when known single gene associations are not detected.
              The approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation
              of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract mechanistic
              insight from statistical associations to enhance the understanding
              of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

            Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach that provides a
            gene module perspective to genetic studies. The flexibility of our
            method allows integrating different data modalities into the same
            representation for a joint analysis. We show that this module
            perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
            influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
            properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological
            perturbations affect genes' activity to exert their effects.
            PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and drug-induced
            transcriptional responses into a common latent representation. For
            this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait associations (using TWAS
            from PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional
            profiles of drugs (from LINCS L1000
            [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a low-dimensional space
            learned from public gene expression data on tens of thousands of
            RNA-seq samples (recount2 [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003;
            @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a latent representation defined by a
            matrix factorization approach [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1;
            @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that extracts gene modules with
            certain sparsity constraints and preferences for those that align
            with prior knowledge (pathways). When mapping gene-trait
            associations to this reduced expression space, we observe that
            diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in
            relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal
            endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
            assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
            tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
            types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
            and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
            associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
            We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
            (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
            and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
            @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
            Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation
            in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with
            modules than with individual genes, even when single genes known to
            be involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide
            significance. Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based
            method also better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by
            capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with
            the mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular
            traits via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease
            prediction suggests that modules may provide a better means to
            examine drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally,
            exploring the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters
            associated with relevant tissues, including a complex branch
            involving lipids with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and
            neuropsychiatric disorders. In summary, instead of considering
            single genes associated with different complex traits, PhenoPLIER
            incorporates groups of genes that act together to carry out
            different functions in specific cell types. This approach improves
            robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic associations, and
            here we show how it can prioritize alternative and potentially more
            promising candidate targets even when known single gene associations
            are not detected. The approach represents a conceptual shift in the
            interpretation of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract
            mechanistic insight from statistical associations to enhance the
            understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

            therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits

          - pass: true
            score: 1
            namedScores: *ref_86
            text: >-
              In this study, we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach that
              provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. Our method
              allows for integrating different data modalities into the same
              representation for joint analysis. We demonstrate that our
              module-based perspective can infer how groups of functionally
              related genes influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct
              transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict how
              pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert
              their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and
              drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent
              representation by integrating thousands of gene-trait associations
              (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and
              transcriptional profiles of drugs (from LINCS L1000
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a low-dimensional space
              learned from public gene expression data on tens of thousands of
              RNA-seq samples (recount2 [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003;
              @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a latent representation defined by
              a matrix factorization approach [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1;
              @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that extracts gene modules with
              certain sparsity constraints and preferences for those that align
              with prior knowledge (pathways). Our results show that diseases
              are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in
              relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal
              endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
              assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
              tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
              types. Furthermore, PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
              and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, allowing for the
              identification of modules associated with cell types under
              specific stimuli or disease states. Our findings replicate in the
              Electronic Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III
              [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225], and
              we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in HepG2
              cells, observing more robust trait associations with modules than
              with individual genes. Our module-based approach better predicts
              FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific
              pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action
              of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known
              immune mechanism). Finally, exploring the phenotype-module space
              reveals stable trait clusters associated with relevant tissues,
              including a complex branch involving lipids with cardiovascular,
              autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In summary, PhenoPLIER
              incorporates groups of genes that act together to carry out
              different functions in specific cell types, improving robustness
              in detecting and interpreting genetic associations and providing a
              better means to examine drug-disease relationships than individual
              genes. Our approach represents a conceptual shift in the
              interpretation of genetic studies and has the potential to extract
              mechanistic insight from statistical associations to enhance our
              understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
              modalities.

              Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
              that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
              flexibility of our method allows integrating different data
              modalities into the same representation for a joint analysis. We
              show that this module perspective can infer how groups of
              functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect shared
              and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict
              how pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert
              their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and
              drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent

              associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
              [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of
              drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
              low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on
              tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use
              a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
              [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003]
              that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
              preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways).
              When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression
              space, we observe that diseases are significantly associated with
              gene modules expressed in relevant cell types: such as
              hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with
              keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood
              cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and

              heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
              associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease
              states. We observe that significant module-trait associations in
              PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic
              Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III
              [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our
              replication cohort). Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to
              analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust
              trait associations with modules than with individual genes, even
              when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not
              reach genome-wide significance. Compared to a single-gene
              approach, our module-based method also better predicts
              FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific
              pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action
              of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known
              immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests
              that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease
              relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the
              phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
              with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
              with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders.
              In summary, instead of considering single genes associated with
              different complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes
              that act together to carry out different functions in specific
              cell types. This approach improves robustness in detecting and
              interpreting genetic associations, and here we show how it can
              prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate
              targets even when known single gene associations are not detected.
              The approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation
              of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract mechanistic
              insight from statistical associations to enhance the understanding
              of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

              ---

              We propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach that provides a gene
              module perspective for genetic studies. Our method integrates
              different data modalities into the same representation for joint
              analysis, allowing us to infer how groups of functionally-related
              genes influence complex traits and predict how pharmacological
              perturbations affect genes' activity.


              In this study, we map gene-trait associations and drug-induced
              transcriptional responses into a common latent representation
              using public gene expression data on tens of thousands of RNA-seq
              samples from different cell types and diseases. We use a matrix
              factorization approach to extract gene modules with certain
              sparsity constraints and preferences for those that align with
              prior knowledge (pathways).


              Our results show that diseases are significantly associated with
              gene modules expressed in relevant cell types, such as
              hypothyroidism with T cells and neuropsychiatric disorders with
              different brain cell types. We also identify modules associated
              with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states, which
              can provide insights into tissue-specific pathophysiological
              mechanisms linked with drug mechanisms.


              Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid
              regulation in HepG2 cells and observe more robust trait
              associations with modules than with individual genes. This
              improved drug-disease prediction suggests that modules may provide
              a better means to examine drug-disease relationships than
              individual genes.


              In summary, our approach incorporates groups of
              functionally-related genes that act together in specific cell
              types to carry out different functions. This approach improves
              robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic associations and
              has the potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical
              associations to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and
              their therapeutic modalities.
            prompt: >
              You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining
              the text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations
              through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and
              drug mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional
              genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug
